novel_text:
The first story about the giant wasn’t told in newspapers but in a drizzle of whispers in line at the food trucks, under porch lights, on the bleachers at the ballfields in Railroad Square, where the grown-ups pretend not to stare at the sky when it goes slate-blue. A child on a tricycle said she heard steps that made the pavement hiccup. A teenager working the kettle-corn stand swore he saw a woman taller than streetlamps but thinner than a storm, cross the lot without moving her knees. A valet outside the refurbed synagogue told his cousin’s roommate that he felt a breath, just one enormous breath, over his shoulder as he counted tips.

On the night Maybelle Jarvis disappeared, no one heard any scream. There were just the fair noises—laughter spread thin, a band failing a cover of a song that should never be covered, someone shouting bingo though it wasn’t that kind of night. There was a pause in the long chain of neon letters that spelled out FRESH LEMONADE, and then a little more pause, and two boys arguing about the rules of tag took half a step backward and bumped into no one. Maybelle’s father tipped his paper cup to finish the ice, frowned at the bitterness, looked down and saw her shoe. It was unscuffed, two Velcro straps, the glitter already flaking off like fish scales. And there were the photographs later, but the photographs came after the whispering had built a mouth of its own.

The photographs were of lips. Not eyes or faces or the way hair falls when you’re not knowing it’s being watched. The lips, only the lips, pursed or parted, some blown up until they became their own landscapes. They were found in a neat fan near the back of the library. The library stayed open late on fair nights because of air conditioning and safety, and because the woman at the reference desk believed in books like you believe in lint you can never quite get off your jacket. The photographs were smudged in the corners as if someone had moved them with hands too large to do delicate work.

People in Tallahassee talk small-town, long-road, quick to think they know the whole of anything. Within two days the giant had a name. They called her Abigail.

She was jealous, the whispers went. That’s why she squished the little ones. Jealous of what, exactly, no one agreed on. Some said of innocence, some said of attention, some said of the shrinking of the country into screens small enough to tuck into a palm. Jealousy was the one word everyone could hold.

On Sundays, Zante preached about envy without naming it. She wore her collar, thin like a ribbon you could cut with your teeth, and stood in the clear-hewn light of the high windows. She was not tall, but there was something in her posture that made people sit straighter. She had the look of somebody who remembers what the backs of stations smell like. In the whispers she had two titles, one of them true, the other more of a shadow that stuck and would not let go: vicar and DCI. She’d been the latter across an ocean, once. The collar had come after the badge, and Tallhassee—she pronounced it correctly most days—embraced her as something rare, a woman who could officiate a wedding and diagram a crime scene and bring casseroles in foil pans that never found their way back.

On the Sunday after the fair, she climbed the three wooden steps to the pulpit and paused, as if listening to the building breathe.

“Coveting,” she said. “We like to save that word for lists. We like to keep it in stone. Thou shalt not. But the hollows in us have better handwriting than stone.”

Abigail sat in the front pew, a smile tucked into her cheek like a coin you don’t want to spend. She had a wide forehead that would gleam when she laughed, and she laughed often, and her hands were always moving. She ran a studio in a small brick unit just off Gaines Street. She photographed mouths precisely because everyone else wanted eyes. She called it honest work, close work. She kept the old cameras on shelves and in glass cases; the digital ones sat in a drawer that stuck. Her prints hung on the walls in the church hall, lips painted, lips chapped, lips child-soft, lips grandmother wise. People said the photographs made them uneasy. People also bought them, because that’s what unease will do when it meets a credit card and a blank spot on a wall.

Some parishioners shifted when Zante leaned into the sermon. She spoke about a neighbor in London who had painted his fence a color that could only be called radioactive apricot. “And I loved my faded fence until I saw his,” she said. “I confess I wanted his fence to peel.” She wore her hair pulled back, no stray piece allowed, the soft drawl she’d learned in Tallahassee braided with a sharper music from other rains. “Jealousy,” she said, “is the crowded feeling. The feeling that says there’s not enough room left for your soul. We do not become bigger by stepping on someone else’s breath, but oh, how we try.”

Abigail’s smile thinned on the word breath. It was subtle, a little thing, and then it was gone.

After the service, the hall turned to coffee and polite noise. Children darted between folding chairs; two slid on their socks along the varnished strip of floor that wasn’t as sticky as the rest. Abigail stood by the window and watched the kids, watched their mouths, watched the words begin and slip and break. She tilted her head. She said to no one in particular: “We promise with our mouths first. We make vows before we learn to write.”

“You’re sermonizing now,” Zante said, warm behind her. She brushed a crumb off the dark sleeve of Abigail’s dress. Abigail tipped her chin, a little defensively.

“You were good,” she said. “Maybe too good. They’re going to want you to save them from a fable.”

“They’re going to want me to visit a fairground,” Zante replied. “And I will.”

“You? Or the other you?”

“The both me,” Zante said, and smiled. She meant the collar and the old badge, the title everyone loved to whisper. DCI. It had followed her like a stray cat across customs, through a courthouse, into a church.

By afternoon, the fair was mostly gone, the temporary lights snapped down and trucked away, the asphalt unrolled again into its usual blank. A few chalk drawings persisted—crooked houses with windows square as teeth. Zante walked the path between the palms, wearing ordinary shoes, the hem of her skirt catching on the weeds that poke where the maintenance budget lets them. Sergeant Boone trailed a few paces behind, big-shouldered, unsure where to put his hands when he was with a woman who wouldn’t take his hat and wouldn’t fit into his ideas of categories.

“Appreciate you coming,” he said for the fourth time, and the fourth time Zante nodded. He’d been the one to call her, late, his voice thick with heat and something he wouldn’t name.

“You’re not technically my parishioner,” she said. “And you’re not technically my officer.” She crouched near a puddle, peered at the ripples the wind made. “But technically is thin ice. We stand on thicker things.”

“We found these,” Boone said, and opened a paper bag that had grease shadows from the lemon doughnuts people had been choking down with beer. Photographs slid into Zante’s palm. Lips. So close-farmed that you could see the powdery coat of sugar on one mouth, the cracked dentist-candy stripe on another. One set that looked bruised but might only have been painted purple in the way children paint. No teeth show. That fact bothered Zante in a way she did not explain even to herself.

“These were left in the playhouse by the swings,” Boone said. He was gentle with the words, like they could break into panic in his throat. “Kids go in there all the time. Moms sit outside and scroll through. It’s not their fault. I keep telling anyone who tries to say that.”

“It is no one’s fault to trust a soft afternoon,” Zante said. “Is it a single photographer?” She tilted the stack so that the light passed again over the glossy prints, saw the same slight misalignment in the grain of the paper. The same font on the back, a series number. Each print signed with a single initial—A.

“The rumor,” Boone said. He flushed. “The rumor is stupid.”

“What rumor isn’t?” Zante looked at the puddle again, then at the footprints hardening into nothing. “Say it.”

“The rumor says she’s huge. Like folklore huge. Like she stepped straight out of some old bedtime tale and got mad because no one tells bedtime. Like she’s jealous that everything you could ever want to watch is in your phone, and nobody leaves milk or coins on the windowsill anymore. I know. But—”

“She?”

“Everybody says she. They call her Abigail. Don’t know why. The name’s just there now. Like a... hitchhiker you can’t not see.”

Zante said nothing for a moment. Abigail. She rolled the name slowly through her mind, as if it had grown spines overnight. Her Abigail was probably arranging prints on a studio wall, glass of water sweating a ring onto the old table she refused to refinish. Her Abigail would say I told you, with no smugness, just the frankness that had seduced Zante’s caution into sleep.

“You have the parents somewhere quiet?” Zante asked finally.

“At home,” Boone said. “The girl’s father’s a baker. He’s been bringing loaves to the station since my first day. I want to bring him something. Past the mail, you know? But what do you bring. There’s no—” He cut off. In the shallow shade of the live oaks, his eyes were soft and useless.

“You bring your listening,” Zante said. “And polite water. And you bring the truth, gently. And if you pray, you pray first and again later.”

“You think it’s the same as the Killearn case?” Boone asked. “The one with the three Polaroids left in the park band shell?”

Zante turned the photographs over in her gloved hand. The edges of the images had the faintly warm feel of instant film, but the stock was modern. Someone was pretending at nostalgia. Someone wanted to be myth and was willing to buy the supplies.

“If it’s the same, it’s the same person finding a new height,” she said, not answering the biggest question. “Or pretending to be bigger. You like the word giant because it lets you stop making small choices.”

Boone frowned. “You think somebody’s staging the footprints?”

“What footprints?” Zante hadn’t looked for prints yet. It wasn’t as if there would be prints, big or otherwise. But at his face, she straightened and followed his gesture.

He led her to a long shallow mark along the grass. It hadn’t rained, but the sprinklers had done their midnight work. The imprint of something long and flat had pushed the blades down in an oval. Another, twenty feet away. No toes, no heel. As if a rowboat had taken a stroll, skidding on its underside in slow arcs.

“Kids tried to stand in them,” Boone said, a little fierce. “We sent them home. Ground’s already springing up, see? The earth forgets quickly.”

Zante went on one knee and placed her palm on the crushed grass as if feeling a pulse. The day-long heat rose into her skin.

“If you had a huge foot, you’d leave more than this,” she said. “If you had a cart on skids and a telephone pole, you might mimic it with some practice and whiskey.”

“But why?”

“Because someone wants us to look up. Because someone wants us to tell a story about big things.”

Boone swallowed, his throat working visibly. “We’re missing a girl. I don’t want to look clever on the news. I want—the obvious.”

“I have never once found the obvious to be anything but rude,” Zante said. Her voice softened. “I know what you want. I want the same. And I want a world where no one whispers children’s names in the wrong past tense.”

That night, Abigail came home late, smelling faintly of developer and something sweet and a little too coppery. Zante was at the table with three notebooks and a bowl of cherries. She wrote with a pencil. She always had liked the impermanence of lead.

“You came home,” Abigail said, in a tone that made it sound as if the choice were surprising every time.

“I do that,” Zante said, not looking up yet. She finished the sentence she was coaxing, placed the pencil carefully on the open page.

“Everyone asked me if I’m okay,” Abigail went on. “At the studio. As if the weirdness is a smoke only some lungs deserve.”

“Are you?” Zante’s eyes met hers. Abigail’s pupils were bigger than the light warranted; they tended to be that way at night.

“I am the okay that everyone else can stand,” Abigail said. She walked to the sink, ran the tap, let the glass fill and overflow into her hand. “You were at the fairground?”

“It’s just a parking lot now.”

“They found pictures again.”

“Yes.” Zante tapped the edge of her notebook. Her days were built of facts and fissures. “Mouths,” she said.

Abigail hoisted herself onto the counter, her bare feet swinging slightly, touching the cabinet doors like metronomes. “People don’t like mouths,” she said. “They like the idea of the eye, the soul-window, whatever. But the mouth is the errand-runner of the soul. It’s where the promise goes from thought to thing. That scares them.”

“It scares them because it betrays them,” Zante said evenly, and Abigail smiled, because Zante understood the work even when she wasn’t trying.

Abigail’s hair smelled like rain and metal and something else. Zante lifted her own glass, took a sip, and waited for the part of the evening where the quiet unclenched enough to be named. Abigail let the faucet keep running and then remembered and turned it off with an apology to no one.

“I heard it again today,” she said.

“Heard what?”

“The name. Abigail. The giant. It’s almost funny until it puts its hands on your back.”

“It’s a name like any other.”

“It’s mine.”

“We can share it,” Zante said, but there was a small press in her chest she refused to call dread.

“Do you think she’s real?” Abigail asked. She was watching Zante’s mouth. She did that when she wanted to borrow a truth.

“I think people are missing,” Zante said. She got up to rinse the cherries. She did not say that the story of big feet is easier to hold than the story of a hand that fits inside a doorjamb.

“When you were a detective,” Abigail said, “did you ever have to consider a suspect twice because you loved them?” She said it like a thought you’d throw away if it didn’t catch air.

Zante turned, slowly. “What is this.”

“I’m asking.” Abigail slid down from the counter, her feet soft on the floor. “Hypothetically. You know how people are. They gossip. They say. They’ll look at my cameras, my lips. They’ll pick at names. And you’ll have to talk to me like I might be a person who...”

“Who what?” Zante’s voice sharpened, then softened again. “You are not the rumor. You know what I think of rumors.”

“You think they’re lazy.”

“I think they’re hungry and have terrible table manners.”

Abigail lifted her shoulder. “It’s a good line.”

“It’s also true,” Zante said. “Do you want to tell me something, Abi?”

Abigail’s mouth tightened, then loosened. She had a beautiful mouth. People had told her that all her life. It had made her practice closing it.

“Only,” she said, “that I’m colder when I should be warm. It’s August and I keep getting cold.”

Zante crossed to her and touched her arm, felt the fine cool sweat there. “Hot then cold,” she said. “That’s Florida. The AC everywhere is a sin and a kindness.”

“I’m jealous,” Abigail said suddenly, the word leaving her almost by accident, like a hiccup you’d hoped to swallow. “Of all the little people who know how to be just that. Little. Quiet. Loved for it.”

Zante felt her eyebrows lift.

“I should have been born a bird with a long shadow,” Abigail said. She laughed, but it was a brittle thing. “Forget I said that.”

“I won’t,” Zante said softly. She put her palm on the back of Abigail’s neck. She could feel the muscle, the slow tension. She could never quite tell where Abigail ended and performance began. Maybe that was true of everyone. Maybe that was why Abigail’s photographs unsettled, because mouths forget to perform when they’re close enough to the lens to feel embarrassed.

Outside, a truck downshifted and groaned like old bones. The house took the sound and held it in the eaves. Zante went back to her notebooks when Abigail slipped into the bath. She could hear the water running again. She ran her finger along a line she’d written and wasn’t sure she agreed with herself. Sometimes the pencil seemed to have its own notion of truth, and she let it.

At midnight, the phone in the hallway rang once, twice, a little too fast. Zante lifted it and said hello in a voice that apologized for being awake.

Boone’s voice came back, almost a whisper. “We got something. You’ll want to see.” He gave her the address of a park at the edge of town, where the lakes smelt like their own summers, where the boardwalk creaked under tourists and joggers and children throwing bread that wasn’t for birds.

“I’ll be there,” Zante said.

“You didn’t ask what.”

“I have stopped asking that on the phone,” she said, which was true. The answer was always someone’s breathing or the lack of it.

She wrote a note for Abigail and placed it on the kitchen tile because the counter was still damp. Gone to help Boone. Back before the light grows. Love you. She stared at the Love you, turned the pencil to the eraser, then didn’t. She left it alone. They had an agreement to make statements and not undo them in the small hours.

The park was empty except for the kind of empty that is actually a chorus. The insects stuttered and sang, the water moved its small shoulders under the stars, someone in a house across the way told an unhappy dog that everything was fine. Zante pulled into grass and killed the lights. She saw Boone’s silhouette near the boardwalk rail and another smaller shape crouched in the waiting posture of those who have learned not to move until asked.

“Detect—” the smaller shape said automatically, then stumbled. “Vicar. Sorry.”

“Zante works,” she said. She recognized Lyle, the forensic tech whose hair looked always recently cut by a friend. He handed her a flashlight, its heft like something old-fashioned and comforting. Better than those too-bright LEDs that erase shadows. She liked shadows to speak before she forced them into confession.

“It’s not blood,” Lyle said quickly. “Just paint. On the boards. It’s washed where the sprinklers hit, but you can see where they... paced it out.”

Paced. There were marks—dark, slightly sticky still, in big ovals. Someone had lifted a bucket and set it down in a pattern that implied strides. Farther apart than a human’s could be, unless the human was running hurdles with a freakish efficiency. The ovals were not perfect. They were overwhelmed by their own attempt at hugeness.

“How many?” Zante asked.

“Fourteen,” Lyle said. “It ends by that bench, and the last two go off into the grass, where everything’s too messy to talk back.”

“And here,” Boone said, lowering his voice further, as if the lake might eavesdrop and repeat him to trees, “here we found this.”

It was a picture, of course. Lips, of course. This one smaller, printed on thinner paper, not instant film. A child’s mouth, a missing tooth. The kind of raw gap that makes a smile look new-made and hopeful. There was a ring of sticky red around the edges as if someone had colored outside the line. But the red was nothing that belonged to a body. It was the same paint that had made the walking ovals.

The picture had been propped against a pair of flip-flops. Blue, with a cartoon fish embossed where a big toe would rest. Size small enough to break your heart.

“They’re Maybelle’s,” Boone said. “She got them yesterday.”

Zante put a hand on the back of the bench so she could feel something that had not been moved. The night pushed softly into her lungs. She kept her eyes on the lake, because sometimes if you did not stare at the thing that frightened you, it would walk into your peripheral and reveal itself as a smaller thing.

“There’s a pattern,” Lyle said, because that is what forensic techs like best. “Three days between this and Killearn. Two weeks between Killearn and the one at Levy Park. And—”

“We’re going to stop the pattern,” Boone said. He said it like a spell he wanted to believe in. He looked at Zante. “Right?”

Zante felt something old shift inside her. The thing that made her cruel when she needed to be, and kind when it cost her. The thing that had gotten her out of high-visibility jackets and into a collar she had truly chosen. The thing that could flip between interrogating and absolving without moving her feet.

“We’re going to interrupt it,” she said. “We’re going to make it trip on itself.”

“How?” Lyle asked, breathless, young.

“By refusing to play big,” Zante said. “By letting small see us.”

They worked the scene until the sky forgot its dark. Zante watched the sprinklers come on and glitter the paint into lesser ovals. She watched the mist hover around Boone’s shoulders like ghosts of possibilities, then fall. She watched a heron decide that the day was coming and would not be argued with, and she admired it for the indifference.

At home, the house smelled of shampoo and sleeping. Abigail lay on her side, one arm flung above her head like a flag. Zante’s note was at the edge of the rug where a shoe could catch it. The pencil mark of Love you looked stodgy in the early light, and for a second Zante thought about writing the words again, soon, in a way that didn’t look like a homework answer. She brushed hair from Abigail’s cheek and saw a faint smudge along the jawline, the color of the paint in the park when it had been thinned by dew.

“Camera smudge,” Abigail murmured, half-awake. “Don’t interrogate me in bed, Zan.”

“I wasn’t,” Zante said, even though she had been, with her eyes.

“You smell like grass.”

“I’ve been in it.”

“Everything is a sermon,” Abigail sighed. “Even your being in the grass.”

Zante undressed and stood a minute at the window. The neighbors’ cat.
The slow dawn. The city stretching off its small aches. She thought about feet. She thought about jealousy. She thought about vows made with mouths, and about how some people used cameras, and how some people used stories. She thought about the name Abigail, and about how names can be so light and so heavy at once, like a balloon tied to a stone. She thought about the bench by the lake and the flip-flops and the gap in the missing tooth, that little square of truth, and she prayed without words, because words had taken the night off.

She slept then, a little, and dreamt of walking ovals. In the dream, the ovals lengthened and shortened depending on how fast you believed. In the dream, someone very tall stooped to enter a doorway that insisted on being ordinary, and the stoop was the saddest part, not the height.

The week moved. The heat drew everything sticky. People came in to talk to Zante and left again leaning against the doorframe for an extra second, as if touching wood would rub off a blessing. Middle-schoolers traded dares at bus stops about keeping a coin on their tongues for an hour to confuse the giant. Someone made a T-shirt with a crude drawing of a woman stepping on a line of faceless stick figures and the caption Don’t Be Little. The T-shirt sold out fast. People wore irony as a kind of sunscreen.

“Come tonight,” Abigail said one evening, shoving a postcard toward Zante. “Opening at the studio. Lips and Lies. I figured if they’re going to make me the villain, I may as well curate the exhibit.”

“It’s a bad time to invite eyes,” Zante said.

“It’s a worse time to hide,” Abigail said. She had written the title on the card herself in a hand that looked like it had never been taught to compromise on loops. “People are going to put me in your rumor whether I ask them to or not. Let me choose the frame.”

“I have to meet Boone,” Zante said, and saw the small jealous flare in Abigail’s face like a match that wanted to be a torch and knew better. “I’ll come after,” she amended. “I’ll be late, but I’ll come.”

“Bring your collar,” Abigail said, half a joke, half a dare.

“I always have it,” Zante said, which was usually true. The white strip of faith in a world that would try to tear it from her, or tuck it in her pocket. She liked how it made people remember their own sentences.

That night, a storm bruised the north, then decided to make up and took its lightning elsewhere. Zante and Boone sat in a patrol car outside a park that had not yet been blessed by rumor. They watched the emptiness, and they waited to interrupt a pattern. It was boring, and Zante loved it. Patience was a cathedral.

“They’re baying for a giant in my inbox,” Boone said, tapping his phone and then turning it face-down as if that could hush it. “Parents. Reporters. Strangers. They want one big story they can fold into a headline, one big villain to feed and chase.”

“The greatest kindness you can give people,” Zante said, “is a smaller story.”

“You talk like a vicar.”

“Because it’s true,” she said. “And because you want me to say I don’t believe in giants. And I don’t. And because I know that sometimes the small person inside someone very ordinary learns to make their shadow big.”

“She or he,” Boone said, careful.

“She,” Zante said, and even the word felt complicated in her throat.

When the night was far along and the crickets were exhausted with their own insisting, Zante’s phone buzzed. Abigail: the opening is a circus. Wish you were here to bless it and also curse it.

Zante: I’ll come in an hour.

Abigail: Promise with your mouth?

Zante smiled in the glow. She typed, Yes. She put the phone away and peered out at the line of cattails doing their careful dance.

The trap they had set was not clever. They had left nothing obvious to tempt anyone. They had simply been present where a pattern said someone might come. Twice, a raccoon considered them. Once, a boy on a bike stopped and stared and then pedaled away, singing under his breath to prove that he was fearless. Zante watched the path and the dark and the places where the dark was lighter, and she thought of the opening with its wine and its lips on walls, and of Abigail in her dress with pockets, joking about being a myth in comfortable shoes.

At almost midnight, across the way, something moved. Something that could have been a person but felt like a mistake the landscape was trying out. The motion had a slow deliberation. Zante leaned forward. The figure paused by the bench. It was wrong in the scaling—too tall and too thin, as if legs that didn’t belong to the torso had decided to attend the event and make the torso catch up. The head turned toward them. The face was a blur of shadow.

“Don’t switch on the headlights,” Zante said, in a voice that contained a steel buckle. “Don’t. Let it think we’re just talking. Let it try to be a legend.”

Boone’s hands were white on the wheel. Lyle, in the back, held his breath like it owed him money. The figure took a step—long, improbable. It carried something in both hands, held out and low, as if serving a tray of pieces of night.

“What’s that,” Boone whispered.

“Photographs,” Zante said. “Or the opposite of.”

The figure reached the bench and arranged its objects there, tender as a nurse with a sleeping child. Then it straightened and did the thing that made Zante’s heart misstep: it lifted one foot high, too high, held it, and brought it down slowly, deliberately, like an actor hitting a mark that had been taped to a floor no one else could see. The sound it made was not the sound a true giant would make. It was hollow and a little ridiculous and precisely what the rumor had ordered.

“Now,” Zante said, and Boone flicked the headlights and the siren yipped to life, once, twice. In the sudden glare, the figure panicked. It turned half-sideways. For a heartbeat, Zante saw the long shadow of it peel from the ground and curl back. She saw the contraption that graced its legs—stilts strapped to thighs with smart leather, the kind used in the circus and in protest marches, the kind you could rent from a place in the warehouse district if you gave a good reason. She saw a mask that was in fact a hood pulled low, and the glint of a lens hanging at the throat like a small, rude heart.

It ran. Or tried to run, but stilts aren’t good for running, and stories aren’t good for fleeing when the truth has put on its boots. Boone and Lyle were out and moving, and Zante was out too, not trusting her own knees and trusting them anyway. The figure kicked and faltered, and in three fast seconds they were on it, and the figure was on the ground, and the stilts lay akimbo like arguments that had never been persuasive.

“Hands,” Boone said, and the figure lifted them.

Thin fingers. Black gloves. A ring on the fourth finger left hand, scratched.

Zante felt the world do a peculiar slide then, as if the angle of the ground had shifted by a degree.

“Take off the hood,” she said. “Slowly.”

The figure hesitated. Then obeyed. The hood fell away. Hair, damp with sweat, and a face that had learned how to be two things at once, and a mouth Zante knew well enough to name.

“Abi,” she said, impossibly calm, impossibly not calm. “Get up.”

Abigail looked up at her wife. The eyes were dark, the pupils bigger than any night required. Her face held no surprise. It held a weariness, a relief, a defiance, all slipping surfaces.

“I walked too big,” Abigail said, voice raw like rope-burn. “You wanted small.”

Behind them, the lake sighed. In the bench’s shadow, under the hard blankness of the headlights, a fan of photographs shone. Lips, lips, lips. Little ink notes on the backs in Abigail’s precise hand. Names. Dates. No graphic cruelty, nothing you could hold up to a court and say Look, look what she did. But every image a trespass, a taking.

Boone made a noise like swallowing a nail. Lyle whispered what people whisper when any magic turns into an ordinary mess.

Zante said nothing. She held her collar with one hand, felt its edge. She tried to make the world stop its slide and stand still enough for her to meet it. She looked at Abigail—the woman from the front pew, the woman who had caught a bird with her bare hands once and set it free without leaving a feather behind, the woman whose jealousy had always been beautiful when it was about little things, sweaters at thrift stores, bruised peaches, other people’s fences.

“We’re doing this here?” Abigail said, and smiled, small and crooked. “With the mouth you told me to trust?”

Zante looked at the stilts in the grass, at the ring on Abigail’s finger, at the way the truth had decided to dance just out of time. She wanted to say a thousand things, each weighted, each a vow or a curse or a prayer. She wanted to say: There is a big story. She wanted to say: You are not a giant. She wanted to say: Stop being the weather in other people’s skies. She wanted to say: I love you. She wanted to say: My love is smaller now. Or bigger. Or sideways.

In the end, she said only: “Take a breath.”

Abigail did. It sounded, for a brief, aching second, like the first breath any child ever takes when it decides to be here. Then the siren yipped again, as if to remind the air of its other uses, and the night went on being night, in the way it does, even as all the names inside it shift.By morning the city had learned to pronounce what happened at the lake in three different ways. In the first version, the police caught the giant, easy as catching a frog in a coffee can if you have the timing. In the second, a woman on stilts proved that everyone was stupid for believing anything larger than a shoe. In the third, the vicar’s wife was an artist who confused the size of her feelings with the size of her body, and the vicar had the look of someone who had mistaken love for a reliable witness. Radio hosts chewed the facts until they were flavorless and then spit them between jokes. The meteorologist used phrases like unstable air mass and everyone heard unstable and wished they didn’t.

They put Abigail in a room with a camera and a table so clean the light invented fingerprints to feel useful. Boone would have preferred to hand her to strangers in suits, but Tallahassee doesn’t have as many of those as a bigger city, and besides, every stranger in a suit eventually wants to talk to a vicar. Zante stood in the hallway with her collar in her pocket because she did not trust what it would remind people of, and also because the plastic chair there made wearing holiness feel theatrical. She could see Abigail through the slat of the blinds. It felt indecent, the way watching your own house from the sidewalk feels indecent even when you have a key.

“You can’t be in there,” Boone said for the fourth time, and the fourth time Zante said, “I am not in there, Sergeant. I am in the hall, being furniture.” He ran a hand over his jaw and made a sound that was part apology and part relief. The two of them were learning the choreography of impossible days. Don’t call it a dance. No one was wearing the right shoes.

They sent in a woman from Records who knew how to ask stupid questions that get smart answers. “Name?” she said, and Abigail, thin shoulders set, enunciated each syllable like a bead on a rosary. “Occupation?” “Photographer.” “Do you enjoy your work?” “Enjoy is a fragile word.” It was theater, and it wasn’t. Every interrogation is a performance, but the good ones allow the actor to forget she is acting for three minutes and in those three minutes she tells you where the doorway is.

Zante did not watch when they read the rights. She did not have a taste for the sound of law being recited like weather. She looked instead at her own thumbnail and saw a crescent of blue paint she had missed in the early kitchen light. It wasn’t a sign; it was contact. She had touched the bench, touched the photographs, touched a night that had touched everything and everyone. She rubbed the paint away against the seam of her trousers and felt like a magician with no tricks left but misdirection.

Abigail did not ask for a lawyer for precisely twenty-seven minutes. Then she did, and the room halted like a toy train, and all the adults in the hallway remembered they were in a building where the vending machine was always empty of Dr Pepper. Boone cursed softly at the air, and the air didn’t change its mind. They set it up for morning, a lawyer from a firm with a name like a polite cough. Until then, nothing big could be said, only small questions with answers that were shaped like fog.

“Is she going to tell us where the girl is?” Boone asked, and Zante realized the pronoun had proven too cumbersome for him to adjust. She did not correct him. You spend all your corrections on the things you can move.

“She will tell you what she has made,” Zante said. “She will not tell you what she hasn’t. Not because she won’t, but because she can’t. She doesn’t have it in her mouth.” It was an odd phrase, but it felt right. There are truths you can hold easily in your hands and others that you can hold only with the tongue, tasting their shape until the taste becomes a word.

The statement they were allowed to take was small. Abigail admitted to the stilts. She admitted to buying paint in three colors because art school had taught her that the eye wants variation even when the lie is monochrome. She admitted to placing photographs “as a conversation,” which is the kind of phrase that makes a detective rearrange his expression so his face doesn’t blurt his opinion. She admitted to moving Maybelle’s flip-flops because “they were sad by themselves.” She did not admit to taking Maybelle. She said the name carefully each time, as if it might shatter if any syllable grazed a tooth. When asked where she found the flip-flops, she said near the edge of the boardwalk, “caught on a knot the city has never sanded,” and Boone wrote that wording down because exact phrases sometimes point to places the body misses.

“You didn’t call anyone when you saw them,” the woman from Records said, not with accusation, but with a steady kind of disappointment, like a grandmother who has found beer in the garage and wanted craft and found cheap.

“I left them where the city would look,” Abigail said, and then closed her eyes as if hearing herself from somewhere slightly to the left. “I wanted them found by a story. I should have wanted them found by a person.”

“You made the giant,” the woman said. “Or helped it be made.”

“People were hungry and I brought spoons,” Abigail said, and something like shame passed through the room and briefly wrung it out.

They booked Abigail on anything they could book her on without pretending the justice system was a vending machine. Tampering. False reporting. Trespass. The phrases didn’t sit well on the desk. They were technicalities trying on moral suits. Boone filled out forms because his hands needed the ritual. He called the man with the stilt rental, who said yes, that girl, she had cash and a face made of daring, and he had asked her what she intended and she said “height,” and he had told her to be careful, because height is a thing you fall from.

When Zante stepped outside, the humidity sat up and asked her what she was doing. The parking lot’s glare was church-bright; everything honest looked guilty in it. She thought of going home and decided that home wasn’t a place she could put her body without her mind starting a fire there. She drove instead toward Gaines Street, the part of town that had rehearsed being a different city and then decided to keep its old name. The studio’s windows were still crowded with last night’s faces, framed and lit so that mouths took on the reckless power of eyes.

The key under the third potted fern worked. She had it because Abigail had made the concept of spare keys feel like a trust exercise she liked winning. Inside, the air smelled like chemicals and the ghosts of fruit, the way a candy store might smell after it had decided to get serious. The floor had paint on it that had been there long enough to form its own opinions. On the big worktable, a fan of contact prints; the panes of small pictures felt like a child’s game that had become something else when no one was watching. Names on the back of some, just descriptors on others. Tooth. Sneeze. Summer. Promise. There was a system and it offended Zante that she couldn’t see it at a glance.

She didn’t touch anything she couldn’t justify later. She walked to the back room and found the drawer that stuck and opened it anyway with a patience Abigail rarely used. The digital things nested there like insects that knew they were useful but pretended not to be proud of it. One camera was on and shouldn’t have been. Zante picked it up and cooed the way you coo to something you suspect will bite. The screen showed thumbnails of mouths, yes, and between them, three photographs that were not mouths: a boardwalk knot close-up, the kind that catches a strap; a child’s glove, the cheap stretchy kind, balled in the angle where a bench meets shadow; and a paper cup from a lemonade stand, crushed, with the word FRESH interrupted by a thumb.

She did not take the card. She did not even scroll. She put the camera back where it would look like indifference. She stepped to the sink. On the lip there was a dotted line of something that looked black and was, when she rubbed it, a deep purple. Lipstick, the kind chosen by people who want to look like a bruise is a decision. Abigail didn’t own that shade. Abigail said colors were better when they asked for forgiveness before they suggested sin. Someone else had been in the studio, or someone in the studio had borrowed a mouth.

On the drive to the Jarvis house, the road’s heat shimmered like an afterthought the sky had already regretted. The street had the kind of trees that make you think cities forgive more than they do. Maybelle’s father opened the door with the expression of a man who has been taught for years how to greet, and woke to find he had forgotten his manners. He was not wearing his apron; he was wearing an old T-shirt that said HOLE FOODS because bakers make puns or endure them. The living room had a couch that had taught generations of naps how to behave. The shoe from the fair sat on a chair by itself, as if time-out might staunch the bleeding of absence.

“We’re not the police,” Zante said, and felt the lie in the second syllable. She was the police in a way that couldn’t be turned off. She introduced Boone because manners are a rope you can hold even when the bridge has fallen. She did not apologize for breathing their air.

“My daughter won’t even know she’s missing,” the father said. “She’ll think she’s in a line for something fun and she’ll be so patient. The patience will kill me.” He rubbed the back of his neck. His hand stopped at the crest of muscle again and again like a wave that didn’t believe in the shore. “They said you caught…” He didn’t finish the sentence. You don’t put a wife’s name on a hook in a house where photographs of field-day ribbons hang.

“We caught a theater,” Zante said gently. “We did not catch what we need.”

He nodded and led them to Maybelle’s room because people do that, as if rooms can offer the kind of answers people won’t. It was small and intentional. A poster of a whale with its rib lines drawn like the bars on a musical staff. A book on the bed open to a page where someone had underlined the word lighthouse because Maybelle had liked how solid the H looked. The second flip-flop was not there. Zante had not expected it to be. On the dresser, pennies in a dish. Boone looked at them like they were a test. He and pennies had history; every cop has at least one useless object he has sworn allegiance to because on one day years ago it felt like a talisman.

“Was Maybelle at the library a lot?” Zante asked, watching the father’s eyes, because eyes are where homes speak when they think they are being polite.

“Air conditioning,” he said. “And because the woman at the desk told her she had the best questions. Didn’t answer them. Just told her the questions were heavy in a good way.” He breathed out and his breath stumbled on a word that wouldn’t form. “We were there that night, before the fair. Not long. She wanted to show me how the printer makes everything smell hot.”

The library held onto cool like a principle. The reference desk woman wore her hair in a bun that had graduated from experiments to policy. She remembered Zante by name because people in this city remembered in a way that felt like a habit you could lean against. “I know you’ll ask what I saw,” she said, and then paused to slide a returned book under the scanner like a priest laying a wafer on a tongue. “I saw mouths. Or rather, I saw not seeing mouths. People always talk with their hands when they’re being quiet. When that fan of photographs was lying there, the hands in this room got loud.”

She told them, and it was mostly absence. Someone had placed the lips by the stacks, someone with hands that didn’t want to be careful and tried to be anyway. She had put them in a folder because that felt less like touching and more like respect. A girl with a gap in her teeth had laughed when she saw the pictures because losing a tooth is the only time that the body’s losses look like wins. A woman with purple on her mouth the color of night flowers had leaned too close to the prints, left a smudge that refused to be only ink. “We don’t get a lot of lipstick here,” the reference woman said with quiet scorn. “Mouths here are mostly practical.”

“Night flowers,” Zante repeated. The phrase fit the color she had found on the sink. She asked for camera feeds she knew wouldn’t exist in any way that would help. The library has cameras the way museums have cameras: to prove they cared after the fact and to offer grainy ghosts that cannot be forced to testify. She watched Maybelle and her father move through a frame like a lesson in how to be small and still be the center of something. She watched a woman with a wide forehead pass behind them, caught for a second and then gone. She watched herself watch and felt the day shift again, slow and mean as molasses.

In the afternoon, the press conference tasted like pennies. Boone stood and said the words that would stop other words from eating him alive. “We have a person of interest,” he said, because that phrase allows everyone to hate without a name tag. “We are pursuing all leads.” “We ask the public to refrain from speculation,” he said, which is like asking rain to refrain from wetness. He did not say Abigail’s name, and the name got said anyway. It threaded through the crowd, softened, sharpened, lifted like a kite, got stuck in a tree.

After, in a corner where the paint had decided to peel, Zante stood with a woman whose child had been found once, a different year, a different park. “They made this city a monster,” the woman said, and then caught herself and said, “No, that’s wrong. The city has a monster. That’s the way to give the sidewalks a chance.” She squeezed Zante’s arm and left, walking with the stride of someone who refuses to be late for anything anymore.

The lawyer arrived with a briefcase nothing important would fit into and a voice that had learned how to sound like a fence. Abigail met him with relief and annoyance. “You’ll tell me not to tell them everything,” she said. “You’ll hide me in words like possibly and allegedly until I can’t find my own hands.” He raised an eyebrow, and it was a better answer than a rebuke. Abby listened with her shoulders but not with her eyes.

When they sat again, the room hummed with the kind of quiet that checks wristwatches. The lawyer said no questions about the child and Abigail said I will answer anything that is a sentence I have written. Boone nodded as if that were reasonable and then asked three unreasonable questions, because that’s the way they teach you. The last one made something in Abigail flinch like a deer remembering the geometry of a road.

“Who else has a key to your studio?” he said. “Who else has been in and out this past week?”

“Lots of people were there,” she said. “Opening.” She counted on her fingers without looking. “Constance with the red scarf and the opinions. The student who told me I had too much ego and then bought a print. The man who said his wife wouldn’t let him hang my work in their house but he could hide it in his office. The night flowers woman. She said she cared about mouths because her lips were the only part of her face she could afford to change.”

“The night flowers woman,” Zante said softly, because the word had sat too comfortably in the slot. “Purple lipstick. Did you know her name?”

“She told me three different ones and I liked all of them,” Abigail said. “She said lies have the best phonetics.”

Afterward, in the hallway where the air struggled to be neutral, Boone pulled Zante aside. “We’re not going to be able to hold her on anything very useful,” he said, and the word useful felt ugly even in a place that turned ugliness into procedure. “We can get her for theater. We can’t get her for the child. If she’s not where the child is, keeping her here leaves us with our hands around a ladder while the fire climbs.”

“Let her go,” Zante said, and she didn’t know whether she was speaking as a vicar or a detective or a wife or a selfish human who wanted to not have her home emptied of a shape. “Follow her with every shadow we can afford. And take me with you when you go small. Big has wasted us.”

They went small. They went to the fairground lot again, not to step in the long ovals, but to put their faces close to gum and bolts and the way gravel remembers. They talked to teenagers who had learned how to withhold because adults treat their rooms as crime scenes. They talked to the kettle-corn boy who gestured with a scoop like a conductor forced to use a ladle. He said he saw a woman that night who wasn’t tall enough to be a giant and wasn’t trying. She wore a denim jacket in heat that had no business tolerating denim, and she spoke to children in a voice that made the word buddy sound like a contract. She had nails painted a flat pink that made Zante think of erasers.

“Could you smell anything?” Zante asked, expecting the answer no, because smell is the first sense that gives up when faced with popcorn. But the boy, surprised by his own yes, said that the woman smelled like eucalyptus and something else he couldn’t name until he blurted “coins.” Zante felt the shape of that in her ribs, a memory of walking toward a subway once in a city where the air tastes like pennies and rain. Eucalyptus and coins. Mouthwash and blood wouldn’t be too dramatic if you stretched. She put the picture in a book in her head that she keeps by feeling.

They knocked at a door two blocks from the library where a woman with night flowers on her mouth would have liked the rent if you believed in stories that tidy. The woman who answered wore chapstick and a stare that had no patience for metaphor. She was not the person they were looking for. But she knew someone who loved purple without irony and she wrote a name on a receipt and the name was the kind that shows up in friends lists like a thorn. Constance with the red scarf, who had argued with Abigail at openings and then moved into her light like a plant.

Constance’s apartment was full of books that had decided to live in stacks instead of shelves. She opened the door with the irritated kindness of someone interrupted in the middle of a page and therefore in the middle of a life. She admitted to loving lipstick. She admitted to hating that love mattered. She denied moving flip-flops. She said that if she were the kind of person to take a child she would take one from another city because she hated hurting her own reflection. It was a terrible joke and the kind that signals a person who uses humor like bleach. Zante watched her hands. She didn’t see the telltale paint in the cuticles. She saw something else: the nervous habit of touching a front tooth with the tip of the tongue, as if checking for a hole that had never existed.

When Abigail returned to the house—released on a cloud of conditions that sounded less like mercy than like homework—she paused on the threshold the way a person does when a familiar room has been repainted in their absence. Zante stood at the table with her notebooks open as if she had never left them. They looked as if they had been accused. The bowl of cherries had gone sad. Abigail’s shoulders were high enough that her ears could rest on them if they wanted.

“They’re going to watch me,” she said, and her mouth shaped the word watch like a child shaping the word monster after checking under the bed and finding an old shoe. “Are you going to watch me?”

“I watched you before,” Zante said. “Watching is what I call love when I’m feeling noble.”

“You could have left the collar on when you came to the hall,” Abigail said, pretending to be casual and failing in a way that made the truth more handsome. “Might have made you immune to seeing me the way they want you to.”

“I took it off so I wouldn’t use it as a shield,” Zante said. “I don’t believe in shields unless they are made of quieter things. Like bread.”

“They went to see Maybelle’s father,” Abigail said. She was very bad at hiding that she knew. Some part of her had always studied networks like other people study weather. “Did he bake for them?”

“He let us into his house,” Zante said. “He let us into the room where the whale poster is. He has the good kind of patience.”

“I didn’t take her,” Abigail said, and this time there was no theater in it. It arrived in the room with its shoes untied and its hair sticking up and asked for toast. “I wanted to be taller than I was and I took that where it could be applauded. I left props. I hated how the town talked like a chorus that never learned the melody. But my hands are not where that girl is.”

Zante believed her the way you believe a sky: not because you are an expert on atmospheres but because you have spent enough time under one to recognize the difference between a threat and a promise. It wasn’t exoneration. It was weather for one day. She crossed to Abigail and put a hand on her cheek and felt a faint grain, as if a fine sand had blown in off a beach that had no business being this far inland. Makeup, cheap powder, too pale, somebody else’s face rehearsed on hers.

“Who touched you?” she asked, and in another room in another decade that question would have been different.

“Everyone likes to touch a photograph,” Abigail said. “Last night they touched me instead. It made me feel like a stair.” Her laugh was small and unconvincing. “One woman told me her mother used to press her mouth to the bathroom mirror so hard it squeaked. I don’t know what that means, but I can’t stop thinking it.”

They slept badly. Zante woke at three to a siren in the distance that meant nothing she could fix. She padded to the window and watched the square of yard that had not decided between being grass and being sand. Under the streetlight’s unkindness, a cat considered its body an adequate argument. Zante thought of jealousy and breath and how people make vows with mouths and then use them to invent emergencies. She thought of the park bench and the knot in the wood and the idea of a woman who would put on a denim jacket in August out of habit, the way you wear an old sorrow because it fits.

In the morning, the message on her phone was from the person you want messages from and dread anyway. Lyle: We ran the paint. It’s theater paint. The kind the university buys by the gallon. We also found fibers on the flip-flops. Carpet, synthetic, low-pile, the color of dust. Not from a house I’d like to live in.

Campus connected the dots if you looked at it with the kind of eyes that had been trained to connect dots even when dots refused. Constance taught two adjunct classes there when the department remembered to send emails. The man with the stilt rentals had once sent flyers for a circus workshop that no one attended because it was held at noon on a Wednesday. The library’s purple-lip woman had a student ID with a name that no longer matched her face and she had taken out books about stagecraft and about reptiles because every person’s curiosity is more interesting than their guilt.

They went to the theater building and walked past set pieces that look handsome only under light that no one brought. The shop smelled like sawdust and paint and the kind of ambition that never makes it to a marquee. A student with a ponytail that looked like a rope pointed them to a shelf where open gallons allowed their skins to form. The purple was there. A list on the wall in dry erase marker said: Please, for the love of god, relid your paint. A person named JESS had drawn a flower in the corner and the flower looked tired of being petals.

“Do you know a woman who wears denim in August?” Zante asked the rope-ponytail, and the girl smiled because that is not a useful question and yet it is, sometimes. “Sandra,” she said, and pointed with her chin. “Costumes. She’s got opinions about temperature and hasn’t lost to it yet.” Sandra had opinions about everything, including who should be allowed to borrow shoes. She had a line of cheap flip-flops under a table, sizes for quick panic fixes onstage. One pair was blue with a cartoon fish, but not the same as Maybelle’s; the fish’s eye was lazy where the fair pair had been alert. “We get donations,” Sandra said. “People bring us their castoffs and blessedly have no idea what actors will do to them.”

In the costume office, a cup sat abandoned that had the ghost of eucalyptus across its rim. The smell of coins was less polite. A roll of Velcro lay open on the table, its hooks mean and wanting fabric. Zante stood still long enough to feel the building admit it knew the rumors and that rumors are a kind of lighting cue. Boone lifted the roll, set it down, lifted it again because his hand needed to move because his heart was deciding whether to run.

“Small,” Zante said, and he nodded and went to find Sandra, who turned out to wear denim in defiance and also because her office has air-conditioning issues that no one in Facilities has bothered to fix since 2009. She had the purple on her mouth, yes, but it was the wrong purple, a berry, a forgiveness. She had a smile that looked like she had forgotten to be careful with it.

“Children?” she said, when they asked their too-careful questions, and her face rearranged itself into something older and knotted. “No. God, no. I sew for middle-school matinees. I know their noise. I am ruined for evil.” Zante believed her and collected a thread from her cuff anyway because belief is not the same as proof and because sometimes it’s good to have a cup you won’t drink from.

That afternoon, the river of whispers funnelled through the church regardless of whether the doors were open. People came in and offered Zante casseroles made of beige and their opinions made of bolder colors. Somebody asked whether she would still counsel couples given the circumstances. Somebody else offered to pray for her in a tone that suggested prayer as a weapon. She stood long enough that the skin between her toes remembered sandals as instruments of patience. When the building was as empty as it could manage, she went to the hall and looked at Abigail’s portraits. Mouths, yes. Lines at the edge where words have worn at the skin like tide. A child’s mouth dressed in careful chapstick because a parent had decided that stage had rules.

Under one frame was a card that had fallen, or been placed. It was not Abigail’s handwriting. The loop was closed where Abigail’s would have risked an opening. The card read: We take from where the talk is. If you want quiet, teach your town to swallow. It was ugly and it was the most honest thing Zante had read all day. She pocketed it not because it was evidence yet, but because it was a map.

That evening, when the sky had stopped pretending blue and admitted to bruise, Zante sat at the small table and lined up the small things. The paint. The knot in the wood. The smell of eucalyptus and coins. The denim jacket in August, a detail stupid enough to be a signature. The mouths. The way Abigail made big as a form of self-defense and someone else used big as camouflage. The idea that jealousy is not the sin here but hunger is, and that hunger will dress itself in whatever will get it fed.

Abigail came in late again, slower than her usual late. She had been followed by a car that did not signal turns and then did, as if confused by its own choices. She put her keys in a bowl as if putting keys in a bowl could be an apology. She watched Zante watching the table and smiled with a mouth that had practiced bravery and found it heavy to hold.

“You’re putting it together,” she said, and the admission was a blessing or a curse.

“I’m making a small story,” Zante said. “The kind that can go to the door and ask to be let in.”

“And if the door doesn’t open?”

“I will learn its hinge by heart,” she said. “And then I will choose whether to pick the lock or ask the carpenter to come preach to it.”

Abigail crossed the room to the sink and ran the tap too long and then turned it off like renunciation. She was shivering in a way that wasn’t theatrical. “I wished for a giant so that people would look up and find their own height,” she said. “I forgot that looking up is a way to avoid looking down.”

“We all forget that,” Zante said. “Which is why pulpits have steps.”

They sat in the dark awhile without making a metaphor of it. The house breathed around them, the polite exhale of an air conditioner trying to keep up. Outside, a boy on a bike sang too fast for lyrics to take hold. The night was not a villain. It was a stage. And somewhere, a child with a gap where a tooth should be had been taught patience so well she might be using it against herself. Zante closed her eyes and counted the steps to the park bench and back, as if faith were a pedometer that could award her points for distance.

The next morning, Boone called before the light rose to say that a maintenance worker at the boardwalk had found something that wasn’t trash pretending to be trash. In the weeds by the last post, tucked where sprinklers would wet but not wash, a foam cooler sat as if it had learned the trick of stillness. Inside, two cans of off-brand soda, a stack of napkins with a taco truck’s logo, a little animal keychain you buy with tickets and regret. A smell that made the worker step back and then lean forward again because the body needs proof. The smell of eucalyptus, heavy and cheap and angry about being found.

Zante dressed like a person going to a trial she believed in. She put on the collar because sometimes you wear a sign to remind yourself before it reminds anyone else. She tucked her pencil behind her ear because she trusted it to say no when her mouth had not learned how. At the boardwalk she crouched and asked the cooler to be honest. It wasn’t blood. It wasn’t even frightening in a way that would satisfy a headline. It was a kit for pretending to be someone a child will follow. She felt something in her chest that had been pretending to be a stone admit it had been an egg all along.

“There,” Lyle said, pointing with the kind of reverence he reserves for clues that don’t mind being touched. A hair caught under the cooler’s handle tape, pale, blunt at the end, cut by a cheap pair of scissors. They would send it for the kind of test people trust too much. They would get a color and a shape and maybe a name. Or they would get noise. It didn’t matter yet. What mattered was the map the small things made and the way it pointed not to giants, but to hands.

Zante stood and looked out at the water and made herself count fish she could not see. She thought of a woman in a denim jacket and the sound the word buddy makes when you sand it wrong. She thought of a building where the air conditioner still owed favors to 2009. She thought of mouths and the way they promise us and betray us in the same sugar breath. She thought of love and its lousy timing and its excellent precision when it wants to break you kindly. She thought: small. She thought: hinge. She thought: I am coming, Maybelle, with a pocket full of tiny tools and a mouth that knows how to keep a vow in pieces until it’s safe to be whole.Chapter Five

The cooler made a kind of sense once they laid its guts out on the bench and called each thing by its name. The sodas were a brand that pretended to be famous if you squinted at the font—NovaFizz, citrus and cola, the bargain store’s way of being generous. The napkins were from El Rey, the taco truck that parked by different waters on different nights, its crowned avocado logo smug in a way Zante almost admired. The keychain was a neon cat with a bell that would make adults twitch and children smile as if they were hearing destiny in cheap metal. The tape had caught that pale hair under its fold, the blunt end announcing scissors rather than a bathroom drain. The smell of eucalyptus was the loudest thing, shouting in a register usually reserved for dental waiting rooms, and under it was the heavier breath of coins, that copper insistence that the world keeps score.

“Small hinges,” Zante said more to the air than to Boone. “This is a door with a lot of them.” He nodded in a way that meant he would hold one end if she would hold the other. Lyle bagged the bell, the napkins, the hair, doing that neat-handed routine that made him look like he was folding a shirt he was going to give to someone he loved.

El Rey set up on the cul-de-sac by the park on Tuesdays and then moved along the lakeshore on Thursdays where joggers pretended tacos were a recovery food. The owner had a towel over one shoulder and the posture of a man who had invented his own rhythm and would not submit to anyone else’s. He remembered the denim jacket because it made him angry at the heat on principle, and he remembered the mouth because of the purple, the kind of color that warns you toward and away at the same time. “She wanted extra napkins like she was planning to be generous with condiments,” he said. “And she smelled like my dentist but cheaper. She asked directions to Neptune’s, the little arcade by the laundromat. I told her the laundromat is better than the arcade because at least the laundromat gets you somewhere.”

The laundromat had windows that sweated from the inside no matter what the season decided. Neptune’s had carpet that tried to be an underwater scene and failed, the low-pile dust-gray ocean printed with fluorescent fish that had gone tired from pretending to swim. The redemption counter’s bell was the same bell on the neon cat, and the girl behind it—AMBER in a name sticker that had done a tour of duty on at least two shirts—pushed her hair behind her ear with fingers that had learned to count tickets faster than anyone expected. She had eucalyptus breath mints in a fishbowl because she was trying to quit gum and respected the sanctity of the carpet. She had a denim jacket on a hook because the air conditioner was schizophrenic and liked to freeze shoulders.

“You sell those cats?” Boone asked, pointing to the neon herd staring at them with optimism. Amber nodded and flirted her eyes toward the chart that translated tickets into prizes and promises. Zante let the hum of the place file away the noise in her head. Kids shouted at screens and learned early about machines that almost give you what you want. In the back, a door held a strip of light the way a mouth holds a breath. There was a smell from behind it that belonged to a break room that pretended to be a living room and couldn’t afford it: coffee that forgot itself, eucalyptus, a carpet that resigned itself to footprints. The manager was a man whose T-shirt had lost its battle with a logo long ago. He did not want them to look because managers of small empires never want anyone to look. Amber wanted them to look because truth makes teenagers generous sometimes.

“Jess worked last night,” Amber said, when they had spoken about nothing for long enough to qualify as polite. “She thinks a jacket makes an outfit, so she’ll wear it even if it’s a hundred degrees. Purple lipstick because she says if you’re going to be an extra you might as well do it right. She does theater at the college. She makes tall things out of short things and gets mad if anyone notices. She walks in here with a pocket full of quarters like a magician no one hired.”

“Jess,” Zante said, letting the name sit on her tongue long enough to match it to the dry-erase flower the paint room had grown. “Does Jess have more name than that?” Amber half-smiled, because this was a city that likes to give you the first name and make you earn the rest. “Jessamine on her direct deposit. Her email’s got a number and a curse word in it. She says names are mouth-choreography anyway.” The manager muttered that they shouldn’t be talking names with police and Zante said she appreciated his concern and Amber rolled her eyes in a way that means here, take this, we live because we give each other small rebellions.

The locker smelled like eucalyptus the way a glove remembers a hand. Inside, a tube of lipstick called Night Shade 17 had split its black casing and left a smear like a bruise rehearsing. There was a little bottle of mouthwash with leaves on the label advertising eucalyptus as a virtue rather than a sin. The denim jacket had one of those enamel pins on the collar, a whale with lines on its belly like a music staff, and the pin made Zante’s skin say, whale poster, whale in a girl’s room, whales in the ocean of a carpet. She could have built a church on how the world likes to place echoes where we can trip on them.

“She crash at the Lakeway?” Amber offered, without being asked, because gossip is a public service if you aim it right. “Half the adjuncts and half the kids do when their air goes out. Cheap rooms and a pool that no one pretends to use. The manager makes you pay in cash if your ID looks like it has regrets.” Boone didn’t like a teenager knowing what he hadn’t asked yet, and he liked it enough to write it down without letting his hand show its relief. The neon cat on the counter winked because its wire had come loose. Or because the city, for once, was helping itself.

Lakeway Lodge had a sign that believed in cursive long after everyone else had defected to block letters. A plastic banner under the main sign promised weekly rates and cable as if cable were still a promise. The carpet in the lobby was the color of dust. The desk clerk had the plum-colored nails of a person who funds three older sisters’ beauty habits and one younger brother’s phone bill. She looked at Zante’s collar and decided to treat her as a representative of a trust she had never bought into but liked to try on.

“If you’re here to save somebody, I’ll try to speed you,” she said, which was the most honest customer service line Zante had heard in a year. “Jess is in 213, sometimes, when 117 is taken. She pays with quarters when her cards pretend to be shy. She is polite in the way that keeps you from kicking her out but not polite enough to make you write home about it. Are we going to do a television version of events, or are we going to knock like neighbors?”

“Neighbors first,” Zante said. They took the outside stairs carefully, because stairs at places like this dislike drama and announce it with their creak. The sun had convinced the railing to burn what touched it, so Zante held her palms up like a supplicant caught in a lesson. A child in the pool counted the tiles like rosary beads and ignored a sign that told him not to play with divinity. Boone posted Lyle at the bottom of the stairs because someone had to be the person who turns a corner into a perimeter.

They knocked on 213 with the patience a hinge understands. The chain was on because this was a city where habits were a form of superstition. The denim jacket hung over the back of a chair, and the jacket told more truth than the room knew it was keeping. The purple on the edge of the cheap bathroom mirror shouted from under the polite fluorescent. The eucalyptus announced itself like a sermon you hadn’t wanted to attend but found yourself humming afterward. A voice from inside said “Just a second,” and then again with a different vowel because the first second had not agreed.

“Jessamine,” Zante said through the gap, not a question and not a command. “I’m Zante. I’m the vicar, and I’m the other thing, and I’m the person who knows the color of your mouth from two different buildings.” There was a pause that had the shape of a swallow. The chain slid back. The door opened to the width of a palm. Jess had the kind of face that makes you think of stories you were told when you were little about people who live in towers against their will and their better judgment. Purple on her mouth but botched on the left where she had been interrupted. Denim, yes, but short sleeves today, stubbornness compromised by temperature.

“I never took your wife’s prints,” Jess said first, which was the kind of defensive that announces itself as strategy more than honesty. “She photographs mouths like a thief. I steal, but not the way she does.” She stepped back from the door and the room opened in that motel way, a small stage given a single set. The bed had the posture of a thing that had been sat on by a decision. On the side farthest from the window, a child sat cross-legged with more dignity than the bedding deserved. She had a gap where a tooth should be and she was working a knot out of a piece of Velcro as if the world depended on neatness. She looked at Zante with that solemn friendliness children are born with until we train it out of them. She said, “Are you the one with the whale songs?” and relief tried to detonate in Zante’s chest and she held it with both hands.

“Hi, Maybelle,” Zante said, making her voice walk slowly as if it were stepping through long grass. “I’m Zante. I brought no whales but I have a friend who is better than whales at getting you a donut later. We are going to take a walk. Does that suit you?” Maybelle nodded because being asked is a kindness children notice even when they are practicing patience as a weapon. She had a keychain looped twice around her finger, the neon cat trying to be brave with her.

Jess had the wrong kind of shoulders for a villain. They were the shoulders of a slender animal that would prefer to bolt but had learned to stand very still and hope the world can’t count. “I was returning her,” she said to Boone, who had remained in the hallway but had widened the door the way cops widen doors when they want to fit in the law without scaring the paint. “I was going to leave her at the bench again with the little sodas that look like they come from a party and the napkins because children spill and the keychain because children like bells. She wasn’t scared. She’s a serious person. We talked about how paper has a smell.” She swallowed and her throat moved like it was being taught something it didn’t want to learn. “You leave your phones everywhere and I can see the shape of your voices without hearing them. I wanted a room where there were only two voices and they belonged to faces I could keep in my eyes.”

“You took her,” Boone said, gentle as a man can be when the sentence he is obligated to deliver tastes like acid. “You took her from a fair and from a father and you let the city chew itself to keep your mouth busy. That’s not returning.”

Jess had the dignity to accept the word took as the word it was. “I made big because nobody listens to small,” she said, and the purple on her mouth sudden looked like a bruise she had chosen, and then regretted. “It worked as a trick and failed as a life. I didn’t hurt her. I don’t hurt small things. I just wanted the quiet you get when a child decides you aren’t going to fail them for five minutes.” She looked at Zante, not as a supplicant would look at a priest, but as one performance would look at another across a stage. “Your wife’s mouths make people feel seen, but only if they give her their money. I wanted to make a seeing that didn’t need a credit card.”

“There is a father who would sell the sun to get five minutes back from you,” Zante said, not unkindly and not like a sermon. “You wanted a vow to stand still. You used another human to make it. You can’t build a quiet room out of someone else’s breath.”

Maybelle slid off the bed and came to stand with a deliberateness that put her in a different category of human than the adults were managing. She took Zante’s hand like a person signs a document—carefully, with intention, without flinch. “My dad says not to go with anyone who says buddy,” she said. “She didn’t say buddy. She said helper. Helpers are tricky.” She announced this as if she were a judge delivering precedent. Zante could have fallen in love with that sentence the way you fall in love with a window on a day when the light is doing what it remembers.

Boone radioed, used codes that make emotions sound tidy, and the room held its breath around the words. Lyle’s face arrived in the doorway like an apology because somebody had to be that today. Jess sat down without being told, as if her bones had been waiting for permission to remember that we invented furniture for a reason. She put her hands flat on her knees. The purple on her lips looked shaky close up, as if the hand that drew it had been more faithful to thought than to mirror.

The walk down the stairs was a procession that refused myth. Maybelle counted again because counting is how we make ourselves a bridge when the river is rude. The man at the pool said, “Hey, little buddy,” and then blushed and looked at his feet as if language had tripped him. A woman watering a plant too thirsty for its pot called to them that she had been praying all week without specifying to whom, and Zante nodded because faith makes more sense on stairwells than anywhere else. In the parking lot the air did that thing it does in Florida where it tries to convince you it is a substance more than a condition. The sky was the insistent blank of a hospital wall.

Boone’s patrol car had the good sense to be itself. He opened the back door and then closed it again because Maybelle didn’t like the look of a cage even when it wore seatbelts. He put her in the front with Zante and gave her the radio microphone to hold because trust is a thing we can put in hands and have it work. Jess went in the back, and even then she looked less like a captured thing than like someone who had finally allowed gravity to speak. Amber would find out because a city is a room with a thousand ears, and she would sit on the counter and tell someone all about how the police were nicer than television and worse than a song, and someone would make the story about sirens and someone would make it about a vicar and someone would file it in their chest as a reason to be kinder to people in denim whether the day was hot or not.

At the station, the rooms performed their roles again. Jess admitted to painting ovals because she liked choreography. She admitted to borrowing flip-flops because they looked lonely in a photograph and she was sentimental in exactly the wrong places. She admitted to meeting Maybelle at the knot in the wood and saying helper and not buddy because she had been a child once too and had learned the scripts. She did not admit to malice. The law does not know what to do with hunger that does its worst damage by pretending it isn’t hungry. A lawyer would arrive, and the lawyer would wear a suit that made Jess look like something that had shrunk in the wash.

Zante took Maybelle home because there are tasks you do with your own hands or you don’t ask somebody else to be the city you want to live in. The baker father opened the door and did the automatic things your body does when your life returns: he exhaled something older than words, he reached, he checked for all the old evidence of a child, the weight, the heat, the readiness to forgive. He said thank you to everyone and it sounded like a bakery could sound if gratitude rose like bread. He looked at Zante and found in her face the answer to a question he had not been brave enough to ask himself about God and police and whether either could be forgiven for being useful so slowly.

They left them against the whale poster, the rib lines like staff lines a song had finally decided to read. Maybelle held up the neon cat and the bell made a noise you would forgive in any house. She showed her father the knot in the Velcro and he listened like a man who had learned what listening buys you.

On the way back, Boone drove without needing the road to remind him how. He was making and unmaking an expression that had been practicing on him in the rearview mirror for years. “You going to tell the city your giant is a small person with purple lipstick and a jacket habit?” he asked. He didn’t say Abigail’s name. He didn’t say it because he is a man who loves to not step where the ice sounds thin. Zante looked at the way the sunlight made designs on the dashboard that no one would claim credit for, and she decided to practice her own honesty where it was cheapest.

“We built the giant,” she said. “My wife built a piece of her. Jess stood on it because the view is better from up there. If we tell a big story today, it should be that we stopped to count napkins.” Boone grunted and let himself, just for a stretch of road, like the way that sounded. Then he returned to the business of inventorying which words he would have to let reporters steal and which he could keep until they needed to be old news.
