“She crash at the Lakeway?” Amber offered, without being asked, because gossip is a public service if you aim it right. “Half the adjuncts and half the kids do when their air goes out. Cheap rooms and a pool that no one pretends to use. The manager makes you pay in cash if your ID looks like it has regrets.” Boone didn’t like a teenager knowing what he hadn’t asked yet, and he liked it enough to write it down without letting his hand show its relief. The neon cat on the counter winked because its wire had come loose. Or because the city, for once, was helping itself.

Lakeway Lodge had a sign that believed in cursive long after everyone else had defected to block letters. A plastic banner under the main sign promised weekly rates and cable as if cable were still a promise. The carpet in the lobby was the color of dust. The desk clerk had the plum-colored nails of a person who funds three older sisters’ beauty habits and one younger brother’s phone bill. She looked at Zante’s collar and decided to treat her as a representative of a trust she had never bought into but liked to try on.

“If you’re here to save somebody, I’ll try to speed you,” she said, which was the most honest customer service line Zante had heard in a year. “Jess is in 213, sometimes, when 117 is taken. She pays with quarters when her cards pretend to be shy. She is polite in the way that keeps you from kicking her out but not polite enough to make you write home about it. Are we going to do a television version of events, or are we going to knock like neighbors?”

“Neighbors first,” Zante said. They took the outside stairs carefully, because stairs at places like this dislike drama and announce it with their creak. The sun had convinced the railing to burn what touched it, so Zante held her palms up like a supplicant caught in a lesson. A child in the pool counted the tiles like rosary beads and ignored a sign that told him not to play with divinity. Boone posted Lyle at the bottom of the stairs because someone had to be the person who turns a corner into a perimeter.

They knocked on 213 with the patience a hinge understands. The chain was on because this was a city where habits were a form of superstition. The denim jacket hung over the back of a chair, and the jacket told more truth than the room knew it was keeping. The purple on the edge of the cheap bathroom mirror shouted from under the polite fluorescent. The eucalyptus announced itself like a sermon you hadn’t wanted to attend but found yourself humming afterward. A voice from inside said “Just a second,” and then again with a different vowel because the first second had not agreed.

“Jessamine,” Zante said through the gap, not a question and not a command. “I’m Zante. I’m the vicar, and I’m the other thing, and I’m the person who knows the color of your mouth from two different buildings.” There was a pause that had the shape of a swallow. The chain slid back. The door opened to the width of a palm. Jess had the kind of face that makes you think of stories you were told when you were little about people who live in towers against their will and their better judgment. Purple on her mouth but botched on the left where she had been interrupted. Denim, yes, but short sleeves today, stubbornness compromised by temperature.

“I never took your wife’s prints,” Jess said first, which was the kind of defensive that announces itself as strategy more than honesty. “She photographs mouths like a thief. I steal, but not the way she does.” She stepped back from the door and the room opened in that motel way, a small stage given a single set. The bed had the posture of a thing that had been sat on by a decision. On the side farthest from the window, a child sat cross-legged with more dignity than the bedding deserved. She had a gap where a tooth should be and she was working a knot out of a piece of Velcro as if the world depended on neatness. She looked at Zante with that solemn friendliness children are born with until we train it out of them. She said, “Are you the one with the whale songs?” and relief tried to detonate in Zante’s chest and she held it with both hands.

“Hi, Maybelle,” Zante said, making her voice walk slowly as if it were stepping through long grass. “I’m Zante. I brought no whales but I have a friend who is better than whales at getting you a donut later. We are going to take a walk. Does that suit you?” Maybelle nodded because being asked is a kindness children notice even when they are practicing patience as a weapon. She had a keychain looped twice around her finger, the neon cat trying to be brave with her.

Jess had the wrong kind of shoulders for a villain. They were the shoulders of a slender animal that would prefer to bolt but had learned to stand very still and hope the world can’t count. “I was returning her,” she said to Boone, who had remained in the hallway but had widened the door the way cops widen doors when they want to fit in the law without scaring the paint. “I was going to leave her at the bench again with the little sodas that look like they come from a party and the napkins because children spill and the keychain because children like bells. She wasn’t scared. She’s a serious person. We talked about how paper has a smell.” She swallowed and her throat moved like it was being taught something it didn’t want to learn. “You leave your phones everywhere and I can see the shape of your voices without hearing them. I wanted a room where there were only two voices and they belonged to faces I could keep in my eyes.”

“You took her,” Boone said, gentle as a man can be when the sentence he is obligated to deliver tastes like acid. “You took her from a fair and from a father and you let the city chew itself to keep your mouth busy. That’s not returning.”

Jess had the dignity to accept the word took as the word it was. “I made big because nobody listens to small,” she said, and the purple on her mouth sudden looked like a bruise she had chosen, and then regretted. “It worked as a trick and failed as a life. I didn’t hurt her. I don’t hurt small things. I just wanted the quiet you get when a child decides you aren’t going to fail them for five minutes.” She looked at Zante, not as a supplicant would look at a priest, but as one performance would look at another across a stage. “Your wife’s mouths make people feel seen, but only if they give her their money. I wanted to make a seeing that didn’t need a credit card.”

“There is a father who would sell the sun to get five minutes back from you,” Zante said, not unkindly and not like a sermon. “You wanted a vow to stand still. You used another human to make it. You can’t build a quiet room out of someone else’s breath.”

Maybelle slid off the bed and came to stand with a deliberateness that put her in a different category of human than the adults were managing. She took Zante’s hand like a person signs a document—carefully, with intention, without flinch. “My dad says not to go with anyone who says buddy,” she said. “She didn’t say buddy. She said helper. Helpers are tricky.” She announced this as if she were a judge delivering precedent. Zante could have fallen in love with that sentence the way you fall in love with a window on a day when the light is doing what it remembers.

Boone radioed, used codes that make emotions sound tidy, and the room held its breath around the words. Lyle’s face arrived in the doorway like an apology because somebody had to be that today. Jess sat down without being told, as if her bones had been waiting for permission to remember that we invented furniture for a reason. She put her hands flat on her knees. The purple on her lips looked shaky close up, as if the hand that drew it had been more faithful to thought than to mirror.

The walk down the stairs was a procession that refused myth. Maybelle counted again because counting is how we make ourselves a bridge when the river is rude. The man at the pool said, “Hey, little buddy,” and then blushed and looked at his feet as if language had tripped him. A woman watering a plant too thirsty for its pot called to them that she had been praying all week without specifying to whom, and Zante nodded because faith makes more sense on stairwells than anywhere else. In the parking lot the air did that thing it does in Florida where it tries to convince you it is a substance more than a condition. The sky was the insistent blank of a hospital wall.

Boone’s patrol car had the good sense to be itself. He opened the back door and then closed it again because Maybelle didn’t like the look of a cage even when it wore seatbelts. He put her in the front with Zante and gave her the radio microphone to hold because trust is a thing we can put in hands and have it work. Jess went in the back, and even then she looked less like a captured thing than like someone who had finally allowed gravity to speak. Amber would find out because a city is a room with a thousand ears, and she would sit on the counter and tell someone all about how the police were nicer than television and worse than a song, and someone would make the story about sirens and someone would make it about a vicar and someone would file it in their chest as a reason to be kinder to people in denim whether the day was hot or not.

At the station, the rooms performed their roles again. Jess admitted to painting ovals because she liked choreography. She admitted to borrowing flip-flops because they looked lonely in a photograph and she was sentimental in exactly the wrong places. She admitted to meeting Maybelle at the knot in the wood and saying helper and not buddy because she had been a child once too and had learned the scripts. She did not admit to malice. The law does not know what to do with hunger that does its worst damage by pretending it isn’t hungry. A lawyer would arrive, and the lawyer would wear a suit that made Jess look like something that had shrunk in the wash.

Zante took Maybelle home because there are tasks you do with your own hands or you don’t ask somebody else to be the city you want to live in. The baker father opened the door and did the automatic things your body does when your life returns: he exhaled something older than words, he reached, he checked for all the old evidence of a child, the weight, the heat, the readiness to forgive. He said thank you to everyone and it sounded like a bakery could sound if gratitude rose like bread. He looked at Zante and found in her face the answer to a question he had not been brave enough to ask himself about God and police and whether either could be forgiven for being useful so slowly.

They left them against the whale poster, the rib lines like staff lines a song had finally decided to read. Maybelle held up the neon cat and the bell made a noise you would forgive in any house. She showed her father the knot in the Velcro and he listened like a man who had learned what listening buys you.

On the way back, Boone drove without needing the road to remind him how. He was making and unmaking an expression that had been practicing on him in the rearview mirror for years. “You going to tell the city your giant is a small person with purple lipstick and a jacket habit?” he asked. He didn’t say Abigail’s name. He didn’t say it because he is a man who loves to not step where the ice sounds thin. Zante looked at the way the sunlight made designs on the dashboard that no one would claim credit for, and she decided to practice her own honesty where it was cheapest.

“We built the giant,” she said. “My wife built a piece of her. Jess stood on it because the view is better from up there. If we tell a big story today, it should be that we stopped to count napkins.” Boone grunted and let himself, just for a stretch of road, like the way that sounded. Then he returned to the business of inventorying which words he would have to let reporters steal and which he could keep until they needed to be old news.

Abigail was awake at the table when Zante walked in, as if the house had written a play and assigned them their marks. She had two cups in front of her and both had water in them that had quit sweating once the kitchen decided that humidity was an attitude and not a law. Her face was bare of purple. Her mouth looked like itself, not holy and not guilty, just an instrument that had to be tuned daily. She watched Zante the way divers watch weather, and she stood when Zante did because wives have choreography too.

“She’s alive?” Abigail asked, and Zante nodded because she could give that much without scuffing anything. “And the person is not me?” Abigail tried for lightness and tripped, then steadied because the body remembers how to walk even when the mind is inventing ice.

“Her name is Jessamine,” Zante said. “She uses paint and Velcro and props. She likes to make tall things out of short things. She borrowed the city’s patience and it didn’t belong to her. She wanted quiet and she took it the way people take anything in this century—publicly enough to be myth, privately enough to be a sin that only shows its ankles.” Zante sat, then stood again, because sitting made the words perform and she wanted them to pray. “You did not take that child.” She watched Abigail’s face absorb the statement with more caution than joy. “You did make the room where the word giant could sleep.”

Abigail flinched and then rearranged the flinch into something that looked like an intellectual shrug. “If I had built a smaller room,” she said, “someone would have broken it to make it larger. That’s what this town does with art.” She smiled a little and the smile failed, and she let it fail in the way only brave people let expressions fail. “Do I get to be forgiven for wanting height?”

“You get to be forgiven for wanting,” Zante said. “We will have a longer argument about what you did when your mouth wanted and your hands joined in. I will make you angry by bringing bread to that argument and you will make me angrier by being interesting. Today, I am going to eat something red and sweet that is not a metaphor, and I am going to say that I am tired of hunger making us invent giants.” She reached for a cherry, found one that had resisted the house air, and bit it with the clean emotion of an animal and not a priest.

The city decided to be many cities about it, as cities do. Some mornings radio hosts said the word cult and meant church and artist and fan and all the other congregations that give people reasons to leave their houses. Some afternoons a woman standing in the produce aisle would look at a purple eggplant and feel disloyal to lipsticks she had loved. At the library, the reference woman polished the spot on the desk where the fan of photographs had once lay and she did it like penance, the kind that makes you feel useful and therefore less guilty for being complicit in a rumor. At the arcade, Amber put the neon cats on a high shelf for a week as if putting an object up where children couldn’t reach would teach adults any lesson. At church, a child wrote a thank-you with more consonants than necessary, and at the bottom of the letter drew a mouth and labeled it MY PROMISER, and Zante put it on the refrigerator as if paper could make cold useful.

There were still interviews in rooms where light has ambitions. There were still forms to pound with pens that have learned to be patient. There was a court date in a month and then another in a season, because justice believes in time as if time were a reliable actor. Abigail had images to take down from the fellowship hall walls before someone decided to be brave and ask her to. She took them down herself, and she packed them as if wrapping were a prayer. She left one up by accident or design: a small mouth saying a letter b, the shape more promise than sound. Zante left it because when she took it down at home later, alone, it made a noise that felt like the right kind of loss.

On Thursday, the university sent an email reminding people not to take supplies off campus and also reminding them about a lecture on Ethics in Public Art scheduled before the budget would cut such things. Constance with the red scarf came to church without a scarf and without a desire to be seen, and she lit a candle with a force that said she was ashamed of having wanted the gossip to keep being interesting. Sandra in costumes fixed the air conditioner in a way the Facilities men had never thought to try and didn’t tell anyone until it started working. Jess’s lawyer filed motions that saved no one and did not intend to.

At the baker’s shop, a sign went up that said CLOSED FOR A DAY. Under it, in handwriting that had decided to be consistent for an hour, another line: THANK YOU. WE WILL BE BACK WITH HONEY BREAD AND PATIENCE. People read it and felt like they had been given a recipe without measurements, and some of them went home and made a mess that tasted good anyway.

By Sunday, Zante had a sermon and the sermon did not contain the word giant. It did not contain the word envy though she tasted it as she practiced. It had story in it because all the true things do. It had the line about fences and colors because there are jokes you can run like a thread through a cloth when the pattern threatens to forget itself. It had the sentence she had been saving without knowing she had been saving it: “The devil doesn’t need to be big when our hunger is obedient.” She underlined obedient in her notes and then erased the underline because underlines make text look like it owes a debt.

Abigail sat in the front pew as if she had never been anywhere else and made herself a place in the room with her shoulders down and her mouth unpainted. She had learned how to smile without using it as a coin. When the peace passed like a contagion, she took people’s hands and not their eyes. After, she poured coffee and did not give anyone the gift of absolving her early. People came and told Zante small truths: I said buddy yesterday to a child and heard myself; I threw away my purple and felt vain; my husband wants to know if you can bless a boat; my sister asked if God is a rumor and I said only on days when people need him to be. Zante listened until listening made a shape big enough to step into, and then she stepped into it and found that the room inside fit.

In the afternoon, when the heat had remembered to be brief, she walked down to the boardwalk. The knot that had caught a flip-flop strap was still smug in the wood. Someone had sanded it finally, late, like people do the right thing when the story includes a bench because benches remind us of saying yes to sitting. She stood very still and counted the steps a child would take from here to the end where the water looked like it had been ironed by an aunt. She thought of Jess going through her tallness like a ritual and getting tired. She thought of Abigail under glass and then not under glass and how love has never learned moderation. She thought of how mouths get all the blame for promises they did not invent.

Behind her, a boy skidded on his shoes, not his socks, because his mother wasn’t there and he was auditioning for autonomy. He looked up. He saw the sky for once and didn’t pretend it was bigger than it was. He said to whoever was following him, “We are not small. We are just next to very big things.” Zante smiled because sermons sometimes write themselves and you just have to get out of the way. She took the collar from her pocket and slid it into place and felt it click against her throat like a hinge that had remembered which door it belonged to. Then she went home, and when she opened the door, the house made the sound houses make when they are finally full enough to stop performing.

Chapter Six

Courthouses smell like old polish and new fear. The walls are the color of laws that looked good on paper, the benches not quite comfortable enough to tempt sleep. The ceiling lights hum in a way that tells you electricity has its own calendar. Zante sat near the back in a patch of air that forgot to move. She had taken the collar off for that morning because the room already had too many uniforms and she didn’t want her white strip to become another badge in a place where everyone was inventorying symbols instead of promises. Abigail took a seat two rows ahead with a kind of practiced poise that made strangers decide she must be either blameless or very good at being not; there is a way a body holds itself that confuses the jury before any sworn word enters the room. Jessamine came in cuffed, her denim jacket folded under her arm like an argument she wasn’t ready to make. She had no purple on her mouth; jailhouse mirrors are honest enough to put makeup in its correct bin: performance.

The judge was a man who looked like an old piano sounds, all felt and memory. He called the case numbers, and the syllables lined up and marched across the room with the seriousness of soldiers who suspect the war was misfiled. When the clerk asked for names, human names came back and made the air thinner. There was a line in the docket about “interference with custody,” and it sounded like a term for weather, not a trespass of love and fear and loneliness dressed as civic intent. Boone sat next to a State Attorney who had to keep marking his place with his thumb because he had learned law in a room where hunger interrupted more sentences than the bell did. Maybelle’s father came and stood when they asked if he had anything to say, and he did not make a speech; he said only, “She likes the way paper smells when it’s warm,” and the judge nodded because we are allowed, sometimes, to let small facts do the work of large speeches.

Jess’s lawyer spoke about community ties and cars that can be found and jobs that pay by deposit on Tuesdays. He said returning over taking is a mitigating shape. He said there was no bruising, no harm, no exploitation, and the room did a collective flinch because harm has learned to dress politely in this century. He asked for a bond that would not bankrupt somebody already building a life on coupons and the library’s notion of stability. The State Attorney did that reluctant shake of the head that people do when they would like to be kind but have been given a script that flattens kindness wherever it occurs. The judge set a number that would require three aunts and a co-worker and one neighbor who has always liked getting to be the neighbor in a story, and he set conditions like a parent sets table rules—no giant, no props, no children not attached to you by blood or law, check in with a man whose desk is haunted by the ghost of his predecessor’s coffee.

Zante watched Jess watch the floor. She had the look of someone who knows how to be punished but not how to be forgiven. Forgiveness requires more muscles than you expect. Abigail felt the room as a lens; she made herself small without shrinking because she had finally learned that height can be a weapon at the wrong table. When it ended, everyone stood at once because courthouses produce that reflex in bodies; people rise to cover their own discomfort. Boone touched Zante’s elbow in that way he has, a question without a mark, and she gave him a nod that said later, I have to go turn my face back into a thing I can use.

In the corridor, reporters had gathered to make straw into bricks. They had learned the town’s posture, the way Tallahassee leans when it is making up its mind, and they tried to mimic it the way children mimic accents they think will buy them candy. Microphones glinted like lures. The one from the station with a sunrise in its logo asked, “Reverend, will you be stepping down?” and Zante smiled in that specific way that belongs to the guilty and the innocent both; the way that says I intend to answer a different question with the same words. She said, “I will be stepping up to the pulpit on Sunday as usual,” and that was the truth even if it offended the arithmetic of shame. A woman with careful hair said, “Do you feel responsible for the myth?” and Zante said, “We all feel responsible for the myths we feed,” and watched the sentence make itself into three different headlines depending on the edit.

Outside, heat arranged its chairs. The magnolias refused to perform for cameras. In the parking lot, a man with a sign that wanted to be a petition hovered, unsure whether he was here to cheer or scold. Abigail slipped through bodies the way a slim fish does, just enough motion to not be netted. When they reached the far end of the lot, the part with the tree that seems older than everyone’s rage, she stopped and leaned her back against the bark like it might arrest her and was temperamentally opposed. “If I apologize,” she said to Zante without looking up, “will it be heard, or will it just be another photograph of a mouth?” Her hands were in her pockets, and she was terrible at pockets because she always wanted to fill them with the exact thing they were not designed to carry.

“You can offer one,” Zante said. “You can’t decide what it becomes on the other end. That is the most annoying part of mouths.” She wanted to touch her, and she wanted to put distance down between them like a placemat under a sweating glass. She did neither, because both are theater, and theater had complicated their house too much lately.

They closed the studio. Not forever, but into a posture that looked like humility from the street. They took the show down in the afternoon, when passersby were busy assigning their children summer tasks like camps and learning to be disappointed gently. Abigail wrapped prints in brown paper as if brown were a moral. She wrote titles on the back not with names this time, but with numbers, as if she could demote the mouths to inventory and therefore strip them of their power to accuse. In the quiet, the building made a sound it had not let them hear before, a small tick in the back wall where water thought about becoming a stain. “I thought this room was mine,” she said, lighting catching the arc of a nail. “It turns out I had left the door open and the city walked in wearing my jacket and then left without leaving a note.”

“You left notes,” Zante said gently, thinking of the card in the church hall, the closed loop where Abigail would have made an opening. She had it in her desk with the lies people tell themselves about donations and the truth about which casserole pans belonged to which grandmothers. She did not say that she suspected that card belonged to Jess or Constance or someone in their chorus. There are some things you keep in your own pocket until the hinge lines up.

They visited Jess in the county jail because Zante still believed you go to people when their breath is borrowed by institutions and you do not wait for an appointment to make you brave. The jail air had been disinfected into a theology of surface. They sat across glass on phones that multiply pauses and make them obvious. Jess had been given a T-shirt that made everything feel temporary. She smiled when she saw Zante and frowned when she saw the look on her face that said I am undecided between absolution and the kind of love that refuses to be staff.

“You made up the Killearn thing?” Zante asked after the small jokes were tried on and removed for being too obvious. “The band shell Polaroids. Were they you?” Jess shook her head with an impatience that suggested she would correct the whole town's footnotes if they’d let her. “No. That’s how I knew there was an ear for it. Someone else put the first mouths down—three, then five, then the library fan, like someone testing a room’s acoustics. I saw the drift and I joined it, because drift is a current you can surf if you don’t mind swallowing water. I told myself it was art, and then I told myself it was a sermon, and then I told myself it was a mirror, and then I stopped telling myself anything and did the thing I’m booked for.”

“Who started,” Zante said, not because she wanted a name that would let her fold the map, but because names relieve the world of having to carry too much pronoun. Jess shifted, the chain on her ankle conducting impatience the way lightning uses a tree. “I don’t have their face,” she said. “I just have the feeling of hands that don’t like being seen trying to be delicate and failing. You can tell when a big person’s fingers are trying to go small; they smudge corners. The backs of the first ones—old stock, not college lab, a little curl like they weren’t dried under anything weighted. The edges warm. Your wife’s touches are respectful; the first one’s weren’t. She wanted to be myth but she still signed her prints. A different appetite. If I had to guess, the starter wasn’t a photographer. They were a collector making a path back to a shelf they shouldn’t have built.” She said it with that frustrating poet’s authority that turns into fog as soon as you try to pour it into a form.

When Zante left, Boone was in the lobby rotating a paper cup between his palms like a prayer wheel he didn’t believe in. “We’re clearing Abigail off the heavier chatter,” he said, because he had learned to deliver this kind of information directly and without salt. “The city will keep it on the grill until it’s charred, but the file will sit down. Jess is going to get what the book says, minus anything the book has the decency to subtract when a child doesn’t have new scars. I hate how tidy that sounds. You hear anything we can go small with?”

“Someone else started,” Zante said. “Jess says the first mouths weren’t hers. She may be lying. She may also be the only honest person in a week of honest types trying on lies to see if the fit flatters.”

“Somebody brought a spoon,” Boone said, remembering Jess’s phrase, and the words made him shake his head like a dog who walked into the river expecting depth he didn’t get. “We’ll go back to Levy. We’ll go back to Killearn. We’ll go talk to security cameras who forgot what they were born for.”

The bishop called, or rather her assistant called, and the assistant’s voice had the polished courtesy of people who are constantly asked to be the throat for someone else’s mind. “The bishop would like to see you,” she said, and Zante could hear the capital letters in would like the way you hear a key on a ring that is not yours. The office had carpet that forgave sins both doctrinal and practical; the furniture was old in the way that asks for mercy. The bishop herself wore a linen jacket the color of cream and had the posture of a person who lifts heavy things without announcing it, and who has decided that collar and chain can talk to one another without either losing jurisdiction.

“You have been asked for,” she said after the tea and the polite weather. “Asked for and asked about. The diocese believes in your work. The diocese is also aware that newspapers are a kind of sacrament for people who need their absolution delivered on pulp. I will not ask you to stop being what you are. I will ask you to remember that your parishioners love you best when you are at table, not on television.” Zante nodded because this was the shape of the truth and because she loved the bishop for calling television the thing her generation calls it, like the set is still furniture and not a pocket. “And your wife,” the bishop said, with a care that meant she had practiced in her head first. “How is she?”

“Large,” Zante said, and both of them laughed in the careful way women laugh when they have remembered all the ways the world insists on making them smaller. “She is trying to learn to be one size at a time.”

That evening, rain made a decision twelve blocks north and then changed its mind before it reached them. The air remained undecided and therefore punishing. Couples came to the vicarage to talk about ceremonies and vows and whether the phrase I promise is heavier than the phrase I do. Zante made tea she never used to drink before Florida taught her that hot things have mercy when the world is humid and uninterested. She listened, and she offered words like hinges: this is how the door might move without squealing, these are the places that will need oil. When they left, she stood in the door a moment longer than necessary and watched the street like a nurse watches a sleeping patient—not because she expects catastrophe, but because expecting quiet feels like hubris.

Abigail found her at the sink with her sleeves rolled, that domestic pantomime that never worked on either of them as disguise because they were both too well-trained in outsized gestures to pretend to be small without being cute about it. “Constance wrote me an op-ed,” she said, holding up her phone like a carapace. “She called me a mouth-thief and then she praised my craft, and then she said the city had made me its scapegoat and she refused to let me be that. Then she pivoted into calling for more public funding for art and less for police and somehow she made me into both cause and cautionary tale. I should probably knit her a scarf big enough to run for office.”

“You can thank her,” Zante said. “You can also decide not to put your mouth anywhere she has laid traps.” She dried her hands and noticed, not for the first time, that the towel smelled like the dryer sheet of a neighbor with opinions. You become part of a neighborhood by consenting to share the air.

They ate in the lateness, bread and sweet peppers and cheese that had forgiven the refrigerator for being inconsistent. Abigail told stories about past openings in other towns, the way audience members treat art like a blood sport, the time a woman threw wine on a canvas because she recognized her ex-husband’s mouth and the artist said thank you without flinching because the stain improved his point. Zante listened and thought of other rooms, rooms with tape on the floors and a smell of felt-tip pens and shouting, rooms where suspects tell the truth in the middle of a sentence by accident and you can hear it because you have trained your ear to tilt. She told Abigail a story about London, finally, because there are histories you give as gifts to prove that a house is a house and not a storage unit.

“There was a man,” she said, “who carried a ladder in Shepherd’s Bush and he brought it to crime scenes before the police did and placed it outside buildings and everyone would look up and look for windows and balcony doors and they would forget to look at the ground. He put height everywhere. He haunted us for six months. He didn’t commit the crimes. He committed the rumor. He made us bad at small. We stopped him by giving ladders to everyone. We put three ladders at every scene and then ladders became furniture and people stopped hearing the word up. Then we found the person who was doing the harm, and he was tall, yes, but that was the least interesting thing about him. Jess reminds me of him in the way that wanting attention is a cheaper desire than wanting mercy, but both can be dressed the same.”

Abigail smiled over her glass. “You’re going to turn into a book of sermons,” she said. “People will buy it and then not read it and then tell you they loved the chapter on envy because it made them feel seen without making them do anything.” She reached across the table and took Zante’s hand and, for a long breath’s worth, neither of them moved it away.

Two mornings later, at Levy Park, a groundskeeper found three more photographs under a band shell seat where gum had mapped amateurs’ patience. Lips again. Not Abigail’s stock—no signature, blank backs, edges cut with the imprecision of someone using a pair of scissors that had duty elsewhere. One mouth with a chipped incisor, not a child’s, a mark of adulthood carried like a story you tell only when drunk. One glossed thick, a shine the color of cheap cherries. One bare, cracked, the kind of mouth that talks too much outdoors. And this time, under the stack, a coin taped to the wood with painter’s tape, a penny face up and rubbing blue where the copper had argued with the air. Boone sent a picture. The penny looked obscenely earnest.

A note with the photographs, in handwriting that was impatient and therefore beautiful: You took my tall away. I can love small, too. The letters leaned forward as if eager to be caught. Boone called before the message finished sending. “We had eyes on Jess,” he said without greeting. “She didn’t do it. She was with her mother giving intake forms to a clerk who wishes his job had less ink. Abigail was at home, because I know that even if you don’t think I do. So unless we’ve got a third in the choir who decided to start humming now that the other two have solos, this is something old asking for attention again.”

“Nothing is older than wanting to be big,” Zante said. She put on her shoes without looking at them and realized in the car that she was wearing the pair with the sole that thinks gravel is a conversation. At the band shell, the morning had not warmed yet into rudeness. Children were already negotiating rights of way with scooters and chalk. The groundskeeper stood with his hands on his hips like a person who has seen too much rain and not enough roof. The photographs were where Boone had left them, in little numbered tents like campers that had pitched themselves. The penny waited to be made into a metaphor.

“They’re daring you,” Lyle said, sounding frightened and pleased, because he is still young enough to enjoy being in the presence of a good puzzle even when the puzzle punctures a child’s peace in the next county. “They’re saying they can do flat as well as tall.”

“They’ve always been able to,” Zante said quietly. “Tall was sound. Flat is touch.” She held her breath for a second to see if she could make the world hush. The world declined her offer. She leaned on the back of the bench and felt the wood give a little the way wood does when it remembers that trees move in wind and only furniture pretends to be still.

The photographs smelled like the bottom drawer of a kitchen, where rubber bands go to make a nest. The gloss was cheap and tacky at the edges in that way that announces a printer from a drugstore. The scissor line took a hair of image off one edge. Whoever had cut them had not minded amputating that much truth. The penny tape was the same blue that had ringed the ovals at the park. The copper was rubbed, yes, but not by fingers—by cloth, rough, full of grit.

“You remember the coin smell,” Boone said, half a question; he had trained himself to notice which metaphors stuck to Zante’s thinking. “From the taco truck. From the cooler. Whoever loves eucalyptus also loves pennies. Or thinks pennies smell like health.”

“Or thinks the rest of us won’t notice if they put two smells in the same box,” she said, and then, because she can’t help herself, “My father used to put a coin on the table when he wanted me to say something brave. He said if I picked it up, I had to speak. It was a little game. Something about the metal gave my mouth permission. It’s stupid, and it worked.” She touched the edge of the tape with a gloved knuckle and then let it go, because ritual matters even as we find it ridiculous, and because evidence is a sacristy of its own kind.

They canvassed the edges in the way that word has always sounded like a polite storm. A woman running in a shirt that told the world she was a survivor, with nothing specified, said she’d seen a person sitting on the bench like a pen intent on the end of a sentence. Denim jacket again, because Tallahassee doesn’t let go of its own clichés easily. No purple this time. A hat, a flat cap like a costume designer would call a choice. Thin wrists. Long fingers that wanted to argue with tape but had learned compliance. A man unloading cases of bottled water for the community center said he’d noticed the shoes—white, not quite white, gray where the toes meet the idea of walking. Nobody saw the face and everybody saw the shape of the intention.

Back at the church, Zante found an envelope pushed under the office door, the linen kind you save for resumes and condolences. Inside, a photograph—not a mouth this time. A hinge. An old iron hinge bolted to a beam, the metal pitted and proud, the wood furred where fingers check for splinters. On the back, in that same forward-leaning hand: If you name a thing, you give it teeth. Let the door be a door. Under it, a letter A, drawn in a way that was not Abigail’s. Abigail’s A always left the crossbar understated, a whisper. This A had made the crossbar heavy, as if it were building scaffolding. Anonymous is a lazy god. Initials are better stories than letters. Zante sat with the hinge in her lap and stared at the window until the trees began to sway, and then she realized she had been seeing not movement but heat.

She showed the hinge to Abigail and watched her face perform a refusal. “Not me,” Abigail said, and she said it like a person correcting a child’s manners, gentle and without permission for argument. “If I were to harass you with metaphors, I would not get the weight of the crossbar wrong.” She held the card closer, and the pupils widened, the hunter’s dark even inside the prey. “Jess?” she asked, already deciding no. “Constance?” Maybe. “Someone who wants in on the poem.” She put the card on the table like it had to rest.

They did the small responsible things while the city rehearsed larger gestures. They visited the Jarvis bakery; there was honey bread and patience like the sign had promised, and there was a woman at the counter telling Maybelle that she was brave like adults tell children they like their shoes, and Maybelle nodded as if she recognized the currency and was willing to accept it this once. They stopped at Neptune’s to give Amber a thank-you, and Amber made a noise that suggested growing up and kept the neon cats on the high shelf because habit makes you superstitious. They bought a whale pin because pins understand the language of grief and self-protection both. They drove the canopy road where the trees in their tunnel state remind drivers that space is a thing granted, not guaranteed. They did not talk about the letter in the linen envelope because sometimes you let a hinge go unnamed for an afternoon to see if the door behaves itself out of loyalty.

At Levy again that week, a man playing chess on a board he carried everywhere like a hymn told Boone that he had given a woman directions to a workshop about stilt walking at the warehouse space off Railroad, that she had looked disappointed when he told her the workshop had been canceled because the man who runs it had decided to go to New Orleans. The man saw so much because he spends his days moving sixteen pieces on sixty-four squares and everyone believes he is looking only at kings. He had a coin in his pocket, and when he was nervous he spun it on the bench; copper blurred. Lyle watched the spin with the crush of a new religion. The chess man gave the coin away at the end of the conversation and looked relieved, like he had solved a game nobody else had seen.

Zante went to the warehouse and stood in its echo. Stilts leaned against a wall like a congregation that had lost its sermon. The rental man’s ledger had hands drawn in the margins, fingers exaggerated, as if he could not stop thinking about how we hold ourselves up. A sheet of paper thumbtacked and curling said: TALL CLASS CANCELED UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE, and someone had written underneath, in pencil, in a handwriting that refused to be seen, or couldn’t help being seen, depending on your view: short forever. She took the paper because vandalism is a form of donation sometimes.

That night, Zante woke to the house making a sound she did not like—a small, soft knock that wasn’t at the door, a kind of request from inside the architecture. Abigail slept on, breath even, a faithful machine. Zante walked the perimeter like a captain does—hand on the back of the couch, fingers on the window locks, the cat outside in the neighbor’s yard a bright triangle passing through shadow. In the kitchen, under the bowl that always held too many keys because keys reproduce when unattended, lay another envelope from the linen store, a quality that made the hair on her arms stand beautifully. The same greedy A on the back flap. Inside, a picture of a mouth, yes, but not in any of the styles she knew. It was a mouth open not to speak but to sing, the shape of a vowel that lifts the soft palate and changes the shape of the head. The caption on the back said: vow, and under it: the hollows in us have better handwriting than stone. It was her line, from the Sunday after the fair. It had been written cleanly, respectfully copied, and then the A again, scaffold strong.

She did not wake Abigail. She sat at the table with the vow in her hand and thought about trespass that isn’t about breaking doors but about stepping into the words a person uses to make a home. She thought about the ladder man in London and how he never touched a body, and how bodies touched themselves differently because of him. She thought about breath again, and how we all love to hear a person inhale when something surprises them because it means the world got in. She put the card back in its envelope and wrote on the front in her own hand, loop open, crossbar light: do not oblige this. She tucked it at the bottom of her stack of sermons because sermons are the only place in her life where she gets to be in charge of the order of things.

Morning gave her no time for rumination. A call from the hospital asked for a priest for a child who had not been harmed but had learned how harm sounds; a family wanted a blessing for a room because the air had been taught to be suspicious. She went, and she stood by a bed where a television in the corner was arguing gently with cartoons, and she put oil on the lintel because oil behaves like language does—moving into places it has no right to be. She could not make any promises that mattered. She could make sentences. She did that until the room felt less like a secret kept badly and more like a stopping place on a road nobody had chosen.

When she came out onto the sidewalk, Abigail was there in the heat as if she had been drawn, her dress stuck to her in ways that evidence would, if called upon, find familiar. “He called me today,” she said without preface, and Zante knew the he, because every city keeps a short list of men with radio shows who believe their job is to tie ropes around the big story and drag it into the studio for public processing. “He wants me on a panel about forgiveness. He paired me with a man who yells on Facebook and a woman who thinks lipstick is a political party. For balance.”

“You said no,” Zante said.

“I said I would think,” Abigail said, and Zante felt that old slide in her chest, the one that happens when someone you love puts a foot on ice and looks back at you like maybe you’ll call it water. “I thought maybe I could be useful. I thought maybe, if I made small there—if I made the giant joke into a story about hunger instead—maybe people would forget to be harmful on their way home. Maybe I could plant shame in a way that makes flowers, not knives.”

“You can,” Zante said, and it hurt. “You can also be used. Tools don’t get a say in who holds them.” She reached and put a hand on Abigail’s elbow and was brave enough to leave it there. “If you go, go with a rule that you will not break in a chair under bright lights. Write it on your arm. Make it be your bread.”

Abigail smiled, and it looked like how a person looks when she has made a great decision and is perfectly aware it is also a poor one. “I will not perform for absolution. I will not sell tickets to my own penance.” She said it aloud, and the street caught it like a coin and spun it once and then let it drop.

That evening, she went, of course. The station made free lemonade with too much ice and a young producer with a haircut like a manifesto greeted them as if their RSVP had cured his insomnia. The host loved his microphone in a way that made Zante worry for the people in his life. The panel set was three chairs and a table with a plant that had not been told it was a prop and was therefore trying to photosynthesize honestly. The yelling Facebook man wore a shirt that wanted to be an argument. The lipstick-is-politics woman had opinions that would have been difficult to manage even if they had been ten percent less shiny. Abigail wore nothing on her mouth. She wore a dress with sleeves because she had learned something about the intimacy of bare elbows. She wrote her rule on her arm in sharpie, and the young producer asked if he could take a picture and she said yes, because she is generous to a fault with the small ways people ask permission.

They asked her to repent on air. She said, “I am sorry for the size of my choices.” The man said, “Do you believe in evil,” and she said, “Only like I believe in weather. It will pass. It will also come again.” The woman said, “Don’t you see that your lips made all of us—” and Abigail, gentle and dangerous and a person Zante recognized and wanted to applaud and arrest and kiss—said, “My lips didn’t make you do anything. Your mouth did. We are responsible for the tools we pick up when the rumor asks us to build.” The crowd of listeners on the other side of the glass clapped because people love to clap when they have been told a sentence that sounds like wisdom even if it makes them uncomfortable. The host broke for commercials with the air of someone who believes in his own ability to steer humanities.

When it was over and the plant resumed its quiet work without an audience, a woman came up to the glass with a child on her hip and held her hand against the barrier as if blessing a window were a reasonable ask. She had a cap pulled low, a flat cap that belonged to a photograph of a grandfather. She turned her hand over so that the palm faced in, and written there, in blue marker, in a hand that leaned forward into its verbs: If you name a thing, you give it teeth. She smiled in a way that looked less like friendliness and more like the beginning of a negotiation. Then she was gone into the parking lot’s permission and the station’s security guard called after her that she couldn’t smoke within twenty feet of the entrance and she laughed and said she wasn’t smoking and left the smell of eucalyptus anyway.

Zante and Abigail stood under the awning long enough for rain to begin and fail again. The asphalt took the drops and turned them into dark currency, circles that pleaded for greater economics. “The A,” Abigail said, watching the woman’s receding back as if the curve of a human could provide a clue a camera would miss. “She wants to be the author. She wants us all to write around her. She wants to be essential. She wants the hinge to know her name.”

“She will give us something we can use,” Zante said. “People like her always do. They cannot resist the urge to be helpful to their own myth.” She was tired, and the kind of tired that isn’t solved by sleep, and she found herself humming one of the whale-song tracks that had come in a CD with a children’s magazine years before and had gotten stuck in the church’s collection of weird donations. The sound was not accurate; she was not a whale, she was a human, and yet the low moan settled something in her because it was too silly to be holy and too primal to be a lie.

In the days that followed, the hinge notes continued. One under the mat at the vicarage door, a photograph of a chapel door’s hardware with a caption: absolve means loosen. One in the choir loft, tucked under a hymnal whose list of favorites had turned into a ranking and then into a faction, this one a picture of a mouth that was not a mouth at all, but the carved squinch of a grotesque at the roofline of a library across the ocean, the shape of gape changed by weather into meaning. One left on Boone’s desk, without envelope, brazen, a drawing this time, pencil, good pencil, the graphite smudged and then polished by a sleeve, of a penny with a hinge for a face.

“I don’t like being fed,” Boone said, finally, putting both hands on his desk and addressing the wood, because addressing the intangible makes you look dramatic and he had decided drama was hers to provide. “I want to catch the hand on the tray. I want to sit her in a chair and ask her why coins, why eucalyptus, why acting like we didn’t get the child back, why acting like anything.”

“She wants me to preach,” Zante said. “She wants me to build her into a lesson. She wants to be written on. She will not like the font I choose.” She offered the bishop’s courtesy level of smile and then went to sit in the chapel by herself for a half hour because alone is a sacrament when done intentionally. She did not cry because crying is sometimes too uncomplicated for the weather of a week. She did not pray with words because she had used too many lately. She breathed, which is both the smallest and the largest thing she knows how to do.

On Friday night, Railroad Square filled up because art and beer like to be near one another; their fumes make people believe in the possibility of both. Food trucks lined up like friendly animals. A band played a cover of a song that should never be covered and then apologized and then did it again because mistakes become style if repeated with confidence. Children ran a feral school under the tables and invented rules that had everything to do with touch and nothing to do with law. Someone, that someone, managed to put a photograph under each plastic chair at the listening station where the vicar had once danced badly because Abigail had insisted and where the vicar would never dance again unless someone insulted one of the saints personally, in which case she would invent jubilation as a weapon. The chairs creaked and the photographs crinkled and one of the children, of course, noticed first and held the picture up like proof of life.

This time: not lips. Knees. Close knees, turned inward slightly, the posture of the shy and the guilty and the child whose mom keeps saying sit like a person. Knobby, bruised, skinned. Knees with bandages. Knees with dirt. Knees with chalk on them, chalk in the pattern of that day’s hopscotch. On the back of one, a word: kneel. On the back of another, a word: knock. On the back of another, a phrase: do not wash the proof. The handwriting had been the same, the forward-leaning eagerness, the crossbar that knew it was labor.

The air changed. It does, sometimes. It wasn’t fear; fear is sharper. It was attention turning from pleasure to posture, the way a dog turns when it hears its name on a voice that was not speaking to it. Zante handed a photograph to Boone and said, “She’s moving up the body.” He said, “She wants to see how many people will take their hats off because the weather changed.” People bend to pick things up and feel religious. They stood together in the soft noise and watched the city swallow new stories, and neither of them said the words pattern or escalation because they had spent a week teaching those words to sit, and they would not reward them with treats.

When they went home, a package sat on the front step, the kind that announces itself with branded tape and then pretends to be innocent of its own insistence. Abigail’s name. Inside, no note, just a stilt strap, new, leather that had not yet made its decision about the shape of the thigh it would partner, and a jar of eucalyptus ointment you could buy at any CVS within a dash of good intentions. Under them, wrapped in tissue as if a gift, a book of hymns with the title rubbed off the cover by years of fingers. Between pages twenty-two and twenty-three, another envelope, linen, too much money for a person of sense to spend on paper, and inside, an image of a small door in a wall too thick for a house, the kind that makes cities out of pockets. The caption on the back, in that irritating, compelling hand: small does not mean safe. Then, below: meet me where the rowboats walk. It didn’t say when. It didn’t need to. When someone writes you a note like that, they are anticipating you right now, or they don’t know you at all.

They went because of course they did. You go not because you want to play the game but because you want to end it on your own page. Boone insisted on being there because he had a gun and a vest and a refusal to let women he respects walk toward trouble without a person who can be blamed if a report demands it. Lyle came because he would have chewed his own hand off before he let them leave him behind when puzzles are being solved. They did it at dawn because dawn is the hour where the city’s tired lets you see the underpainting. The boardwalk remembered the oval prints; the grass remembered being scolded for lying down. The bench stood and offered its good wood like testimony.

She was there. Denim jacket in heat because her trope had announced itself and she had committed to the bit. Hat low. Mouth bare, which meant she wanted to be believed. She stood with one hand on the back of the bench and the other holding a card she did not relax. They stood a pace away, and Boone rehearsed his hands on his belt, and Lyle looked at the horizon because he didn’t know where else to put his eyes yet. Zante spoke first because that is what you do when you are wearing kindness as armor.

“You came because you needed to finish a sentence,” she said, and the woman laughed, and it was a good laugh, a pleasurable sound, the kind that would make you forgive an interruption in a movie theater if it came at the right scene. “You all came,” the woman said. “Like a choir.” Her voice had the rasp that comes from arguing with air conditioning and then smoking anyway. She handed the card to Zante because she had to give something away to prove she had been here. On the front, the mouth, again, but this one was hers—Zante realized it slowly, as if the recognition had been made to walk. Her mouth, the way it looks when she is about to say coveting or when she is about to say go in peace. On the back, the words: we make vows with our mouths first. The trap was lovely. The trap said: you said this, you started this, you own this.

“I am not your hinge,” Zante said, and it was more tender than she meant it. “You do not get to swing on me.”

“You are every hinge,” the woman said, impatient. “You speak and people lift their hands. You and she made a city that listens to mouths again. Before, they were all eyes. Staring at their phones. I brought pennies. You brought promises. Between us, we made a faith.” She took off the hat and revealed a face that belonged to no one Zante had been saving as a suspect to crush. Ordinary in the way the extraordinary always is once it steps into a correct light. Cheekbones like any, a nose that belonged to its family, a mouth that had been practicing since childhood and was tired. The purple lipstick would have suited her and she had left it off. She wore nails painted the color of erasers.

“What do you want,” Boone said, because he believes in asking that ugly question first so the person can’t pretend not to have rehearsed it. She looked at him briefly like he was a prop she respected. “I wanted to be studied,” she said, and the honesty was not admirable, but it was refreshing like pouring cold water on your own head after mowing a lawn. “When I could not be, I wanted to study you. I want to be in your sermons. I want to be in her photographs. I want the giant to belong to me because you made it soft and I know how to make it sharp.”

“You do not get to hurt anyone,” Zante said, and the woman’s eyes flashed, that quick animal look that proclaims: I know the rule, but I resent the person who recites it. “I didn’t,” she said. “He—that is, whatever you think of as a he, the man who walked a ladder around London in your story—he hurt no one and made all of you worse. That fascinated me. Hurt is so boring. You can measure it. What I am interested in is the way a city picks a word and then carries it like a saint.”

“You brought a child to a motel,” Boone said, gentle, because gentleness makes people tell on themselves. She shook her head as if scolding the wrong parent. “No,” she said. “That was your tall girl who lives on her feelings. I’m flat. I have always been flat. I like tape. I like paper. I like the way a penny looks when the light makes it worth more than it is. My job at the laundromat is to clean the distillate tray in the dryer that no one knows exists; I get the lint that is the little, little of everyone. I wanted to make something out of it. So I did. Did it hurt? No. Did it disturb you? Yes. Good. You were all standing around pretending not to notice your mouths anymore.”

“Your name,” Zante said, not because she would arrest her with it, but because without it, the woman would keep building herself taller. The woman shrugged because she knew that refusing to say your name gives you a longer runway. “A is fine,” she said, and smiled. “It belongs to all of us.”

There are moments when you can feel the city decide. The birds don’t stop; the wind doesn’t lean; but a hundred people somewhere mention a topic at the same time and the word crosses a street without getting hit. Zante felt it then. It would have been easy to lunge, to turn this into a scene with bodies and cuffs and commands. It would have been easy to let the woman write the last card. It would have been easy to be big and hope small forgave them later. She did something ruder and more precise.

“You like coins,” she said. “So here’s a trade. You give me something true, not metaphor, not handed to a photograph to make it into an altar. You give me one place we need to look for a child who isn’t home yet. You know a name. You know a knot. And I will let you keep your A until noon tomorrow.” She held the woman with her eyes in that priest way that only works when the other person has already half-decided to confess and needs a place to put the proper noun.

The woman swallowed. It changed the shape of her face just enough to make her temporarily ugly, which is to say human. Her mouth opened, and for once it was not mythology or mischief that came out. “Lake Ella,” she said. “The canoe rental shed. There’s a space under the steps. There’s a boy who sleeps there sometimes because his mother’s boyfriend’s car has a seat with a spring that makes his back cry. He didn’t come last night. He said he was going to. He smells like cigarettes and detergent. His name is Trey. He plays the game with the pennies at the edge of the boardwalk sometimes. He is the right size for your city to ignore and the right size for me to pity. Go check, and if he isn’t there, look behind the shed where the workmen leave the bags of mulch and think no one knows where they—”

Boone was already on his radio, his voice turning into dispatch shapes. Lyle ran like he had been given a word and told to carry it to the person who says yes. The woman smiled, small and unfaithful. “We are not so different,” she said to Zante. “We both love the satisfaction of a good clue.” Zante allowed herself the cruelty of not answering. She had been practicing.

They found the boy. He had a sock for a pillow and a backpack for a wall and a picture of a dog in the pocket of his shorts and a mouth that had decided to be quiet because quiet kept bruises off his arms. He was not gone; he was missing only in the way the world loses track of people without receipts. They did the small things—water first, not questions. Sit on the step, not the grass because ants make everything worse. Ask in tone, not in filing language. Trey had that bravado used by children who have memorized the names of football teams but not the names of the muscles that ache when they carry groceries for a woman who loves the wrong man. He came with them because Boone had learned to make the front seat of a patrol car more farm dog than squad, and because Lyle had a voice that says you will not be harmed by my applause if you do not deserve it. Zante rode along for nothing more than to do the ancient priest job of bearing witness to an ordinary salvation.

When they returned, the woman in the denim was gone. The bench remembered her the way wood remembers every hand. On the seat, a penny, face up, the copper warmed by the sun that had finally decided to do its job. Under the penny, a small neat card with a mouth drawn rather than photographed, a line of graphite for lips, a soft smudge for breath, and the letter A heavy and sure as scaffolding. On the back: noon tomorrow. The time was a dare, and an invitation, and a promise, and a threat, and Zante laughed without sound because of course the city had produced a villain precise enough to schedule her own climax.

They went home and ate fruit like it was a sacrament, not a symbol. Abigail took photographs of nothing—in the kitchen, the curve of the sink where water decides to go to ground, the shadow that a bowl makes when the light is stupid, the specific way Zante’s left hand holds a fork when she has chosen mercy over anger. They made a list of things they would not do. They would not be baited into spectacle. They would not write her into their vows. They would not let the city’s appetite draft them as caterers. They pinned the list on the refrigerator with a magnet in the shape of a whale because you have to laugh. Then Zante washed her face and practiced saying the word no in three registers—the pastoral, the investigative, the spousal—and found that the spousal one hurt her throat least.

At noon tomorrow, the city would perform for itself. It always does. Zante decided to let it. Meanwhile, there was a boy with a backpack to be delivered to a person who would not turn his back into a map of another man’s temper. Meanwhile, there was a sermon to write that did not contain the word giant and would still be heard as if it did. Meanwhile, there was a hinge in her pocket, linen envelope and all, and it bothered her like a pebble in a shoe because she had not yet decided whether to throw it at a pigeon or keep it under glass. She went to her desk and opened her notebook and wrote in pencil because pencils forgive, and she wrote the unheadline she wanted: We were hungry and we brought bread and not knives, and some idiot turned it into a performance anyway, and we loved them enough to make the stage small. It was not good prose. It was a good promise. She underlined nothing and closed the book on the line and went to find Abigail, who was in the other room, practicing being exactly her own size on purpose.

Chapter Nine

Noon came into the house like a person who had misread the invitation and dressed grander than the host intended. The heat put its hands flat on the windows, the kind of humid insistence that makes even air-conditioned faith feel like it is sweating into its shoes. Zante woke early and let herself be ordinary for an hour, coffee from a chipped mug, the collar set on the counter instead of around her throat, the pencil making short work of a list that was not about strategy so much as manners. She called three people who could be trusted to resist spectacle even when spectacle winked at them, and she asked them to bring bread as if they were going to after-school care and not to a place where a rumor had decided to stage itself. She texted Boone and asked for a quiet perimeter, not the bright kind that looks like a lesson plan. He answered with a thumbs-up she pretended not to find adorable, because some men are allowed the occasional emoji if they have carried other people’s emergencies with their faces too long. She left a note on the refrigerator under the whale magnet reminding herself to say no out loud if her body forgot what her mind had decided, and she laughed once at the absurdity and the necessity of leaving instructions in your own house.

People had chosen to gather whether they had been invited or not; that is the nature of a town that believes in its stories like exercise. The boardwalk smelled of lake and sunscreen and gossip that had been left in sunlight too long. A freckled teenager wore a T-shirt that said LOCAL MYTH ENTHUSIAST and had crossed out MYTH with a thick marker so that anyone reading had to do a little work to decide how funny they found it. Two women in straw hats tried to look like they were here to walk and found themselves checking for cameras without meaning to. An old man with a dog built like a question mark kept his gaze on the water as if to create the illusion of privacy for everyone else. Zante stood by the bench because the bench is where the city had decided to pin its hope and its complaint. She had a bag of coins she had emptied from a jar at the church where people leave offerings that are too small to be formal and too specific to be random; she would not let one woman’s tape make pennies into omens without a fight. She welcomed anyone who approached with the kind of nod you give a neighbor you have not yet decided if you like, and she gave a child two coins and said the lemonade stand that wasn’t there today would be back tomorrow, and in the meantime he could make a wish quietly and then find something else to spend the wish on. He shrugged as if this made sense to him and made the coin spin until it looked like an argument and then he let it fall flat in the shade where even copper tires quickly.

Boone drifted at the edge of things like a rock you forget is in the river until you stub your shin and curse and then apologize for cursing. He had put two officers in plain clothes into chairs with styrofoam cups and a posture that suggested divorce more than stakeout; he was learning how to hide from a city that had been eating uniforms for breakfast. Lyle carried a cooler like any civilian trying to be helpful and kept finding reasons to be at the periphery of clusters of conversation, where the best overheard sentences live. Abigail came late on purpose because she had an instinct for timing and for making timing look like accident; she wore a dress with sleeves and no lipstick and a pair of sandals that made her walk sound like a person, not an entrance. She stood on the other side of the bench and did not catch Zante’s eye until bystanders had satisfied themselves that someone would recognize if the vicar’s wife and the vicar intending to be a person were both here. When they finally met, they did not stage a greeting. They let their mouths do the work of small and their shoulders stay down.

The woman in the denim arrived as if she had been waiting inside the day all morning and had only now decided to present her silhouette. She had chosen a hat that cast her face into a sensible kind of anonymity, a flat cap that a grandfather might have rehearsed being extravagantly ordinary in. Her jacket looked less like defiance and more like habit, and her hands were busy from the moment she stepped onto the boards, the fingers arranging something that resisted arrangement. She brought a stack of photographs tucked under her arm in a manner that made them look like mail she had been entrusted with and not like bait. She moved to the bench in a line that wasn’t straight and therefore human. She did not look at Zante at first; it impressed Zante that the woman knew she was not the only pair of eyes worth courting.

Zante had decided beforehand that she would not let questions be called down into a microphone whose job had only ever been amplification; she would let verbs lead. She turned to the nearest clutch of people and said, “We are going to feed each other,” and she said it in the kind of soft that compels rather than invites. A woman took bread, the good kind from the Jarvis bakery, the crust that had made Maybelle consider growing up in a single afternoon, and then that woman tore it and gave it to a boy whose mother had not remembered cash because the rumor had taught her to leave the house nervous and unpocketed. The boy said thank you without being told, and the rumor had to accommodate good manners, which does not suit it. Zante gave coins to a father and watched him hand them to his child and watched that child keep one and give one back, and in that simple math there was dignity that legends cannot digest without gagging.

The woman in denim produced her photographs and it was always going to be new content. Shoulders this time, the slope of them, the way some take weight like a stone shelf and some take nothing like a promise and some have learned to curve inward in a shape you could call humble and you could call shy and you could call self-protection and you might be right all three times. Scars across one where sun had decided to write and then regretted its handwriting. A white strap line on another that was the opposite of bruise and somehow meaner. A shoulder with glitter stuck to it because small girls like to make their molecules visible. On the back of one, in that forward-handed writing that wanted to be caught in the act: should. On another: shelter. On another: shoulder someone else’s and you forget your own. She did not hold the photographs high. She let people find them. She let discovery give a child the feeling that they had been allowed to interrupt grown-ups with proof.

Abigail watched with her mouth in that line the world had learned to read as either complicity or critique, depending on what it needed. She wrinkled her nose once because somebody’s cologne had overestimated its importance and because the mention of eucalyptus in her head had trained her to sniff, unfairly, for that particular leaf. She saw the woman hand a card to a boy who had the good kind of skepticism in his shoulders, and she saw the boy use his skepticism and take the card anyway and bring it to his mother, who read it and then tucked it into her bag as if evidence should be kept next to wet wipes. Abigail leaned closer to Zante and said, without moving her lips enough to become a quotation, that the woman had a new perfume today that was less dentist and more bee balm, and Zante said that of course she had adjusted; any good actor adjusts with the room.

What Zante did next was not dramatic and therefore had the kind of power that keeps chairs from scooting. In a voice that was not for the microphones because the microphones were busy being turned off by a pair of volunteers who had a way with cables, she said, “We are not going to say her letter at noon today. We are going to say names of things we will not let hunger resize. We are going to make sentences that are small enough to carry home in our pockets and that will not break when they hit the kitchen table.” People looked at her because the collar has that effect and because authority can be made and also has to be believed in a given square of sky. She went first because that is the burden and the privilege of the person who starts the list. “I will keep the shape of water cups holy,” she said, and it would have been ridiculous if not for the cooler and the heat and the knowledge that the first thing people weaponize when panic becomes policy is thirst. A woman said, “I will shoulder my sister’s lease for two months,” and the kid with the T-shirt said, “I will close the tabs on my phone that keep me angry when I could be useful,” and a man with tattoos that looked like they told the truth even when he did not said, “I will stop calling my bad memory selective and call it bad and apologize like it’s unpaid rent.” They went on like that for too long to be interesting and long enough to be honest, and by the end of it the rumor had been made to sit with its hands folded, at least for that hour.

The woman in denim stood and watched and let her mouth become thin the way a person who had planned a party and found another party had brought better snacks lets a disappointment be visible. She put a photograph down on the bench without flourish and the photograph was a mouth again but not a stranger’s, not even Zante’s again; this was Abigail’s, in a frame so tight the viewer could see the unretouched pores at the border where color and flesh dispute territory. On the back, the sentence Zante had used three days earlier and had put back into her notebook like a bird she was not yet ready to release. It was an act of flattery and theft and argument in one, and the woman stood very far away and did not enjoy how she had been written into smallness. Zante picked up the card and put it in her bag because sometimes you refuse to be curated.

Boone let the moment be what it was meant to be and then he did three things so boring they were radical. He walked a slow loop that required people to shift aside and consider that their elbows exist in a world with other elbows. He asked a man wearing a camera neck strap whether the camera had a memory card in it or just a sense of its own importance, and when the man said both, Boone smiled and told him to keep photographing children’s shoes and leave their faces alone. He asked the woman in denim if she would like a drink and then let her say no three times because the third no is where people often put the truth. She declined without offense and he could smell eucalyptus despite her best efforts, less sharp today because hubris had been rinsed off by the crowd’s refusal to behave like an audience.

The card on the bench was not the only offering. Under the boards, in the long shadow that late morning insists on, a paper bag tucked itself into a corner like it had learned the posture of guilt. Lyle’ s foot found it because he has a foot that belongs to clues, always landing a half inch to the left of showy. They did not pull at it with gloved fingers like a television would have had them do. They asked a child to bring his father because children will tell a person everything about a bag if they believe the bag contains nothing they are guilty of. The father bent and retrieved it and when he opened it there were pennies inside, taped together in pairs with the same blue painter’s tape, as if someone had decided that the way to get two mouths to meet was to force copper to kiss. There was also a tube of lipstick, purple ugly as a bruise reheated, with the label filed off like a thief learns to do on his first day of commerce. There was a stub of a pencil of the expensive sort that artists buy to believe in their own lines. No note. The woman had upped the tone and then left it to get sour.

It should have been a crescendo, and it was not, which infuriated the part of the day that had gotten dressed for drama. People left in clumps to go do errands because groceries do not buy themselves and children do not love you more for staying at a scene of adult staging. A handful of teenagers tried to take the painter’s tape and tape their wrists together in the way of kids who are always looking for a permission that feels like rebellion, and a volunteer in a shirt that said USHER and meant it in all the forms of the verb smiled and said no kindly because a kind no, when delivered correctly, can act like the opposite of a dare. The woman in denim stood very still and then very slowly, like a person asking a body she knew too well to perform a trick it had not warmed up for, she rolled one shoulder back and then the other and wiped her face with the inside of her wrist where no one wears perfume. She put two fingers to the brim of her cap in a gesture that was not ownership and not farewell and not, thank God, saluting, and then she walked away without looking back to see who had counted her steps.

Zante sat on the bench when the crowded hour had forgotten itself and the lake went back to whispering and the boards went back to the work of holding the weight of people who do not write myth.
