Abigail joined her and did not speak in the way of two women who know that their contribution for that minute is not to further sculpt language. Boone came and let himself look like a man at lunch. Lyle went to throw something away not because he needed to but because sometimes a body needs to carry trash to a can to decide it did a job. Zante took the photograph with her own mouth on it out of her bag and looked at it for longer than was civilized. She put her thumb over the image and felt the slick surface resist. She did not like being collected, even when the curator swore she was building a museum to mercy. Abigail watched her do it and did not offer to take the card away, although the offer laid itself on her tongue and rolled back like a tide that knew to leave the shore alone when the shore was doing its own thinking.

In the aftermath hours, the city remembered that it had to be a city and not a single rumor. The bishop called to ask whether they had need of casseroles for nobody in particular, and Zante thanked her the way you thank a person offering a blanket when you are only chilly and not in danger. Amber at the arcade texted a picture of a new sign on the redemption counter that read BELLS TEMPORARILY UNAVAILABLE and made a face in emoji because some humor can only be expressed as punctuation. Maybelle’s father sent a bag of rolls with Lyle to the station because bread has never stopped being a form of currency in households where people take the time to knead. Jess called from a phone somewhere in the system and left a voice message that said only, “She hates not being allowed to write the end,” and then a click that was not a hang-up so much as a permission for silence to start again.

The letter that came that night did not travel by envelope; it arrived under the ashtray that had no cigarettes in it because the house refused to become a place for that particular smoke. Someone had put the ashtray there during a party years ago because it felt grown-up and then had never used it. Under it was a folded piece of thick paper that had been cut hastily from a larger sheet, the edge rough as if the blade had needed help and the hand had provided encouragement. Inside, a photograph of a hinge again, not a door this time but a toy chest’s, the brass dulled perfectly by small fingers that had learned how to open and close and be proud. On the back, in that same forward press of letters: you made quiet into a crowd. The compliment was sincere and useless. Underneath, with the crossbar on the A drawn as if she were building scaffolding with impatience: noon did not keep my promise. There was no time set for the next act, which made it worse in the way empty spaces on calendars can be worse than solid blocks.

Abigail sat at the table and pushed her glass into a ring of water and then pushed it again to make the ring larger; she had always liked to watch circles argue with stipulations. “She’s going to go stranger,” she said, because escalation is not always size; sometimes it is novelty. Zante said that the city had not yet recovered from the sound of its own smallness and that might give them more time than they deserved. Abigail said that time in this town is a rumor with a calendar, and then they both let the conversation sit until it forgot to be important. Later, when they were in bed with the fan doing that kind of noise that pretends to do more work than it does, Abigail said, not like a possible confession but like a weather report, that she had thought about calling the radio man back to tell him she had more to say about forgiveness, and that she had not done it because forgiveness is too glamorous a noun for her to be trusted with on Thursdays.

Boone’s text in the morning was the kind that announces small and wins big. He’d sent a photo of a boy sitting on a station bench coloring in a picture of a whale with a blue crayon that had been snapped in two and was therefore twice as useful. Trey had a new shirt because somebody somewhere had decided to keep a closet for such kids stocked not by principle but by habit. The boy had opinions about pancakes that Lyle wrote down because nobody ever gets asked the right questions in rooms like that and Lyle had decided that he would change the intake form to include a space for favorite breakfast foods. Boone wrote, in a sentence longer than his usual patience: Laundromat called. The woman who cleans the distillate tray hasn’t come in. Name on the timecard is Alva. It’s close to an A somebody would choose if she wanted to be biblical while pretending to be anonymous. We’re going to go small at the lint trap.

The laundromat did not mind being a place for theology; it was used to revelations done in hot air and in the quiet between cycles. Alva existed in the log in the particular way that people exist when they are paid in cash and in the relief other people feel when a dirty thing becomes briefly clean. She had a schedule that overlaid like tracing paper with Jess’s old shifts at Neptune’s and with the nights the taco truck had parked itself like a mirage at the lake. The manager, who had the soft look of a person whose day consists predominantly of apologizing to machines and to some lovely extent to people who are machines about their own rituals, said that Alva talked in complete sentences to the washers and not to anyone else. He showed them a crate where she kept her things and it was exactly what you would expect from a person whose handwriting leaned forward: a notebook with pages torn out carefully and pages torn out violently, a stack of photographs of hinges and mouths and child shoulders printed on paper that could not weather a season, a handful of pennies that had been polished with a rag until the date could be read like a hope, a tube of ointment still scented and not cheap. There was a cap that smelled of scalp and lake. There were no receipts, because some people live on receipts and some people avoid them like metronomes because they do not want to hear what they already know.

“Alva,” Abigail said, tasting the name like a vowel she had held longer than is polite. “That’s a grandmother’s name that got lost on the way to a child.” Zante said that names like that teach you to bend into their shape and that sometimes the bending gets mistaken for humility. Boone did the practical things, entered the name into the modest chorus of databases that the department pretended was an orchestra, ran the time compared to Trey’s disappearances and the park’s play of rumor, made himself a small map on a piece of paper because sometimes paper allows you to lie to yourself less successfully than screens do. He circled the laundromat and Neptune’s and the bench with a pen that had leaked in his pocket and had blessed his thigh with a blue he would carry all week.

What they could not do was arrest a hinge, not when it had not been attached to violence. What they could do was refuse to hold it up in the square and let people worship. Zante told the bishop she was going to preach a series of verbs instead of nouns until the town bored itself of language and fell back in love with doing. The bishop said that verbs were always a safer bet and then reminded her to drink water because bishops are allowed, in their broad vocation, to mother the clergy whether they ask for it or not. Abigail planned a show of objects that could not be sold, a room of small things—cracked cups and tape dispensers and cards with grocery lists—photographed so close that even the people who prefer being sentimental about eyes would have to engage with the mouth-equivalents of daily life. She said that if she could trick the city into being bored by scale, she would call it a success. She said it in the tone of a woman who has not yet decided whether she believes in mercy for herself but is willing to impersonate someone who does, in case it teaches her something.

The call came from the library not from the reference desk but from the children’s room, where a volunteer with a voice like felt announced that someone had left coins under four chairs and a ring of blue around the mouth of the turtle statue the city had bought years ago as a reminder that some kinds of slowness are heroic. They went in a cluster because you do not send one person to a place where a turtle has been made into a message. The coins were taped to the underside of chairs like a schoolboy’s stash; the tape was blue but not the same brand as before, and Zante put that into the file in her head labeled improvisation because when a rumor runs low on supplies it becomes interesting. The turtle wore the ring of painter’s tape like a child would wear a ribbon meant for an adult, not quite right and therefore adorable and therefore dangerous. A note, always the note, tucked in the mouth of a stuffed dragon that had lost one button eye, read: the hinge on a book is a spine. You read and I open. The A was barbed now; the crossbar looked like an act of self-congratulation.

The librarian with the bun who had opted out of drama from the beginning set down her scanner and said, in the tone of a woman who has been patient, that the city was doing the thing it always does when it is bored and afraid at the same time, which is to attend to esoteric stationery and leave the person in need standing ten feet away asking for a bathroom. Zante loved her for it, not least because it allowed her to feel vindicated in her campaign against nouns. She gathered the coins, threw the tape in the bin, patted the turtle’s head with the kind of respect you give a public object that has held thousands of children without complaint, and told the volunteer to read something about whales to the group that had wandered over because the vowel is an honest noise and the letter W has always been a hinge in disguise.

That night, under their own roof, Abigail pulled out a photograph she had not shown anyone, not because it incriminated and not because it absolved, but because it embarrassed her. It was a picture she had taken months ago, sloppy and precisely what she loves—an image of Zante’s hand on a page, pencil against paper, a thumbnail with a chip in it, the faint shadow of the ring that had been removed five minutes earlier to have lotion applied. The mouth was not in frame, which made it, for once, about a promise that had been handed to a tool and not to a face. Abigail said that looking at it made her feel braver about her own scale, and Zante said that if bravery could be outsourced to images she would take a subscription and stop speaking for a week. They laughed in the manner of the exhausted, which is to say with more air than sound. The letter under the ashtray glowered politely, and they left it there because some things you do not file and you do not burn; you let them decide what they are by failing to do their worst in your presence.

Morning brought a rain that did not apologize. It hit the city like a plan that had been drawn up by someone who knew everyone’s best excuses and had invited them anyway. The boardwalk went dark and clean and uninterested in carrying anyone’s theater. The turtle under its ring of tape felt less like a prop; you can bathe anything in rain and it becomes briefly its own. The laundromat rattled happily. Neptune’s carpet smelled like it forgave children for being damp. The station phones rang with the usual wrong numbers and two right ones and Boone assigned the right calls to men who pretend to mind being asked to do kindness that cannot be logged on a sheet as crime prevention.

At midday, while the rain did that thing of being noisy and therefore comforting, a package arrived at the church addressed to no one and everyone. It was light in a way that packages rarely are when they have something to prove inside them. Inside, hinges again, a mobile of them, cheap brass and good iron and one that had been rescued from a door that had forgiven many teenagers their curfew. They had been tied together with blue tape, not as an insult but as a sea, and when Zante lifted the thing from its bed of reused tissue, it turned and clicked and produced a music that wanted to be taken seriously. A card fell out, of course it did. The handwriting was the same, the crossbar on the A incredibly proud of itself. On the back: if you refuse to be big I will attach you to everything. It was not a threat and it was not a promise; it was a confession. Zante hung the mobile in the fellowship hall where it would ring every time somebody’s back door opened to let in a casserole. She did it on purpose, and when people commented on how it made them feel clever and also like they were being watched by grammar, she said nothing that would turn it into a sermon because sometimes mothers teach babies to soothe themselves.

In the evening, because even weeks like this must submit to the tyranny of supper, they ate on the porch, and a neighbor’s cat performed murder in the yard with the shamelessness of a creature that has never been taught to be guilty about its own appetite. Abigail told Zante about a call she had gotten from a student who wanted to argue that art is not responsible for the uses to which idiots put it, and Zante said that while this was technically true it was morally lazy; then she softened and said that love is like that most hours of the day as well. Abigail said she had been tempted to develop a series of non-images—white squares with the word MOUTH handwritten at the bottom, the kind of audacity that would make the city snap photos of nothing and congratulate itself on insight—and Zante said she should do it just to get it out of her system, and then admitted that even she would be tempted to buy one because austerity has always looked aristocratic until you have to live with it.

After the plates were put in the sink and the neighbor’s cat had gone somewhere to be terrible in private, Zante sat with the notebook that contained her verbs and she drew a small box on the page and wrote in it: knock. She wrote next to it: kneel. She wrote under it: vow. She drew a tiny hinge under vow because the only way she has ever understood belief is as a series of moving parts that pretend to be whole. She wrote under the hinge: open, and then she closed the notebook because you have to close a notebook on a word like that or it will become presumptuous and invite itself to everything. In the quiet that followed, a drop of rain fell from the gutter long after it had any right to still be there, and in the sound there was a possibility that a rumor would move on and find another town hungry enough to swallow it without chewing. She did not trust possibilities. She accepted them the way you accept a loaf with an uneven crust: with gratitude for its existence and with a knife ready to correct its manners.

Close to midnight, the phone rang, and Boone’s voice arrived at its volume that signals an admission that matters. He said that a custodian at the museum had found a stack of photographs shoved into the mouth of a plaster statue of a woman with an urn because this city will insist on staging its metaphors generously. He said the photographs were throats this time, throats swallowing, throats singing, throats yelling across ballfields, throats with necklaces cheap and inherited and stolen and loved. He said the backs read: call, and under it: answer, and under it, on one: confess. He said there was also a photograph of a hinge mounted to a pedestal with the card that described it like art, and that the card used the word ecclesiastical because Alva had decided to give herself a word she could hide in. He asked if she wanted to come, and she wanted to say no and she wanted to say yes, and because free will is not an on/off switch she told him she would come if he promised to make the museum lights speak softly and not like a courtroom. He said he would try; he is a man who makes promises like that seriously, and that is why she trusts him in the dark.

They went because of course they did. The museum liked being open for the wrong reasons because it was tired of being open only for the right ones. The custodian, whose name had a vowel the city mispronounced and who did not mind because he had decided to put his pride in other words, showed them the statue and then left them alone because he understood that the room did not need another mouth for ten minutes. The photographs were beautiful in a way that made you want to bite something. Throats lifting, throats relaxed, throats with the soft dip where a pulse makes a map and a promise and a threat all in one. On the back of one, in Alva’s hand: I will not use your town up. The letter A’s crossbar bravely announced its own restraint. On another: I will leave you alone if you admit you needed me, and Zante felt actual anger in her lower back, the kind of anger that you do not allow into your shoulders because it would make them speak violently. She said to Boone, steady, that they would not admit that, not into a microphone and not into hands and not into any room that allowed tape to feel important.

The museum’s back hallway led to a door that led to a little courtyard with a fountain that had decided decades ago what its sound would be and had never had cause to change its mind. In a corner, a blue cap lay on its side as if someone had apologized to it for the weather. A penny sat on the lip of the fountain and had gone dull because water refuses to let anyone keep their shine very long. Zante put the penny in her pocket without asking permission and told herself it was because metaphors do not get to be left where birds can choke. She looked up because the stars were relevant; they are always relevant when humans are performing, because they refuse to attend and that is a bracing form of criticism.

She did not sleep much that night and she did not perform not sleeping as a chapel. In the morning, she wore the collar and the dress with the pocket and she wrote in her notebook without making it into a stage. She wrote: open. She wrote under it: I will not build her into a sermon. She wrote under that: I will not forget that coins are money and promises are not currency even if they buy time. She left the house and went to check on the bread for the Saturday feed because people have to eat even when art is staging a revolution, and on the way she passed a boy on a bike and the boy sang the same nonsense song he had sung last week and it made her glad in a way that had nothing to do with language.

At the church, a package waited that looked like every other package and was not. Inside, a hinge—of course—and a photograph of a mouth that was hers—again—and a second photograph of a mouth that was not hers and that she recognized anyway, not from a mirror but from a life. It was Alva’s mouth, bare and chapped and ordinary and therefore exceptional. On the back, in a steadier hand that had decided not to lean forward today, a sentence without metaphor, and therefore, finally, a gift: I am tired. It is hard to not be named. I work at night on the days your town makes the most laundry. I think you would have liked me if we had met at a dryer and not at a bench. I will leave the rest where it can go to ground. Say a small thing for me that is not about God. It was the first time the letter had been lowercased. Zante read it twice and then again, and then she said the smallest thing she could find, the kind of thing that could not be made into a column or a defense. She said, “Thank you for not hurting anyone,” and then she said, “I will not write you any taller,” and then she folded the photograph and put it where she keeps good napkins, because that is where grace belongs in a house that hosts more meals than arguments.

Late in the afternoon, Boone called to say a woman named Alva had come to the station and had asked for him specifically and had sat in the chair like she was the first person to ever do it correctly. He said she had said her name and had said she was done and had placed a stack of photographs on the desk and had looked at him the way a person looks at a doctor with a diagnosis they do not want and will nevertheless memorize. He said she had requested no audience and no panel and no performance, and that he had given her exactly that, and that when she stood up and left she had taken the pennies out of her pocket and put them in the dish by the door we keep for people who believe in exact change. He said there was no arrest to be made, and there was no speech to write, and that he was going to go home and stand under his shower and try to decide whether his body worshipped water or worshipped the idea of washing away a week.

That night, the house was cooler. The city had collapsed into its summer fatigue the way a person collapses into a couch they inherited and didn’t like at first and then found their own curve in. Zante and Abigail sat on the porch and did the thing couples do who have survived a week of being asked to be more than they are; they guessed the neighbors’ dinners and graded themselves on accuracy. A cardinal made the noise cardinals make when they have imagined themselves more important than other birds and then remembered that air does not care. A car passed with the music loud enough to make the air hold its breath, and then the car went on and the air sighed. Abigail touched the place on Zante’s hand where the pencil always leaves a smudge and asked whether it had a plan to be permanent, and Zante said that smudges are how paper forgives us for trying to be precise.

Somewhere else, a woman in denim took off a jacket she did not need and folded it as if it had a memory she respected. She taped the last of her coins together and then took them apart again and then threw the tape out and then took the tape back because waste makes her feel weak. She put a letter with a crossbar that had softened on a table and under it she put a ring she had not worn because tape and rings want the same fingers. She lay down without making her bed think any particular thoughts about her day. She said nothing about God and nothing about art and nothing about cities and nothing about fists and nothing about mouths. She said a small thing for herself: my feet hurt. Sometimes the body will save your life by forcing you to be literal.

On Sunday, Zante preached and did not say giant and did not say rumor and did not say hinge as a metaphor. She said, “We are made of verbs,” and she said, “You do not owe a performance to people who will eat you,” and she said, “If you want to stop saying sorry like a hymn, say thank you like a table blessing instead,” and she left space at the end for quiet, the kind of quiet that is not an emptiness but a bowl. Abigail sat in the front and did not photograph; she let her own mouth be the mouth that listens. After, a woman with purple lipstick that was the right shade this time and a denim jacket she had chosen because the air conditioner in her office was a bully asked if there was a potluck and whether she could bring deviled eggs to something, anything, later, and Zante said yes, bring them on Thursday, we will invent a reason.

That night, under the whale magnet, the list that said no had been nudged by air until its corners curled and it looked like a page that had learned humility. They left it. In the morning someone would open the door and it would lift and fall and someone would say a small thing and someone would say a larger thing and the city would do what cities do, which is to wake up and decide where to put their attention like people decide where to put their hands. Somewhere a hinge would be oiled and somewhere a door would be left to squeal, and in between those sounds there would be a child with a penny and a game and a father who will never again let a giant buy his grief a ticket.
